DOC.HEAD: Hurricane Gustav, Tropical Storm Hortense Grow on Ocean Crossing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thoughout with new storm positions, wind speeds
DOC.TEXT: Newly born Hurricane Gustav spun toward the northeastern Caribbean with 80 mph winds Sunday, tailed by Tropical Storm Hortense in the mid-Atlantic about a thousand miles to the east. The governments of Guadeloupe, Antigua, Barbuda, Montserrat, Nevis and St. Kitts issued hurricane warnings Sunday, according to the National Hurricane Center in suburban Coral Gables. A hurricane watch remained in effect for Dominica, Martinique, St. Martin, Anguilla and surrounding islands, said Bob Sheets, director of the center. At 10:30 p.m. EDT, Gustav, which reached hurricane strength earlier in the day, was centered near 15.7 degrees north latitude, 57.2 degrees west longitude, or about 280 miles east-southeast of Guadeloupe. It was moving northwest near 9 mph and was expected to maintain that course and speed through noon Monday. Maximum sustained winds were near 80 mph and some increase in strength was likely during the forecast period, the center said. Meanwhile, Hortense, the eighth named storm of the Atlantic season, had gathered top sustained winds of 45 mph and was growing stronger, its course turning to the north. At 10:30 p.m. EDT, Hortense was centered near 17.6 degrees north latitude, 40.5 degrees west longitude, or about 990 miles west of the westernmost Cape Verde Islands. It was moving north near 5 mph on a course expected to hold through Monday morning. Forecaster Bob Case said the storms were far enough apart not to affect each other. ``We're not seeing interaction between the storms,'' he said. Both storms were born as tropical depressions off the Cape Verde islands on the western tip of Africa. Such storms, typical for this the busiest time of the Atlantic season, have been among history's worst, forecasters note. Case said a tropical wave, potential forerunner to a depression, was shaping up over western Africa but wasn't of much concern at the moment because of Gustav and Hortense. ``They're keeping us quite busy,'' he said. ``The two of them are plenty.'' Tropical depressions become named storms when their top sustained winds top 39 mph. They become hurricanes if those winds hit 74 mph.

DOC.HEAD: He's Attended Country Music Show 503 Times
DOC.TEXT: Neither injury nor work can keep Johnny Shealy from listening to the Grand Ole Opry. He's been to the Saturday night country music show 503 times. When he can't be there in person, he listens on the radio, as he has done for 25 years. He keeps a log of who has performed every Saturday night and what they sang. He even moved to Nashville from Greenwood, S.C., in 1969 to be closer to the fabled program. He lived in a downtown hotel two blocks away to be near the singing stars, and when the Opry moved to the suburbs in 1974, he moved nearby. He explains his enthusiasm like a simple country song might: ``I really love it.'' In a box in his bedroom are 25 years of logs in notebooks with red covers. If he can't listen on radio, such as in February when he was hospitalized after a traffic accident, he appeals to friends who tape the broadcast. When he briefly took a job cleaning floors at a supermarket last winter, his 11 p.m. reporting time didn't get in the way. ``I just took a radio with me and listened at work, but I had to watch out for the boss,'' he said. ``I'll never quit listening. Only death and taxes will stop me.'' Shealy, 48, who has never married and has worked a series of blue-collar jobs, also has his 503 ticket stubs. The cost of Opry tickets, now $13 and $11, concerns him. His pocketbook can't match his enthusiasm these days. But there's always the broadcast. ``They'll have to outlaw radio before I quit listening,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Group Scraps Plans to Buy `Bowie' Knife
DOC.TEXT: A $3.5 million offer for a knife believed to have belonged to James Bowie during the battle of the Alamo was withdrawn because the dagger's owner refused to have it tested for authenticity. Spirit of the Alamo, a non-profit fund-raising group, dropped the offer, president John Stokes said Saturday. Bartley Dean Moore of Riverside, Calif., said family lore has it that a young Mexican soldier found the knife after the mission fell in 1836. In 1890, the soldier gave the knife to Moore's grandfather in Texas to settle a $5 debt, the story goes. Museum curators and other experts discounted the claim. The fund-raising group, formed last year, had agreed to pay $3.5 million if the knife proved genuine, but wanted tests to determine its age and metal content. All 187 American defenders, including Bowie and Davy Crockett, were killed in the 13-day siege of the Alamo. Legend credits Bowie with inventing what is now known as the bowie knife.

DOC.HEAD: Leftist Rebels Kill Political Activist and Son
DOC.TEXT: Rebels killed a well-known political activist and his eight-year-old son, stopping the activist and his family with gunfire as they took a Sunday drive just outside Lima, police said. Arturo Pacheco, a a long-time member of the Aprista Party of former President Alan Garcia, was killed by a dynamite charge placed on his chest after the rebels stopped the family car, the police said. They said Pacheco had been driving on the main highway east of the city with his four children, his wife and a male employee early Sunday afternoon _ probably bound for his hog farm _ when they were attacked by seven people armed with automatic weapons and pistols. Pacheco and his eight-year-old son were wounded by the gunfire, police said, and the attackers made his wife, children and the employee step out of the vehicle and placed the dynamite charge on his chest. They said the eight-year-old son who died had been struck by three bullets. Authorities said the style and cruelty of the attack indicate it was carried out by Maoist-inspired Shining Path rebels. More than 18,000 people have died in political violence since the Shining Path began its war against the government 10 years ago.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Ambassador Says Dependents of Diplomats in Baghdad Free To Go
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Inserts grafs 11-12, ``Meanwhile, The Washington Post xxx to include report of two Americans detained in Kuwait City
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's ambassador said Saturday the wives and children of American diplomats who fled Kuwait to Baghdad are free to go but that the diplomats will be treated ``just like anybody else.'' Summoned to the State Department for another U.S. protest, Ambassador Mohamed Sadiq al-Mashat said ``we are on the brink of a catastrophe. ... American lives are being risked for no reason whatsoever.'' And yet, the Iraqi diplomat did not register any direct threat to the diplomats or any of the more than 3,000 U.S. citizens trapped in Iraq and Kuwait. Specifically, al-Mashat said ``we are not going to use force'' against the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait where Ambassador Nathaniel Howell and a staff of about 10 are defying an order by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to shut down. ``We haven't touched any embassy there,'' the Iraqi said at an impromptu news conference after a brief session with David Mack, a deputy assistant secretary of state who had called him in. Iraqi troops appeared outside the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait City on Thursday night and, according to U.S. officials, have blocked entry and exit ever since. U.S. officials said the embassy's electricity was cut off Saturday at about 4:15 a.m. EDT and water was shut off sometime later. Telephone service is sporadic, though embassy contact with Americans in Kuwait continues. ``A small number of Iraqi soldiers remain outside the embassy,'' the State Department said. ``No attempt has been made by them to enter the embassy compound.'' Al-Mashat said he had no ``official word'' on whether that was true. Meanwhile, U.S. officials said the embassy was operating on generator power. Meanwhile, The Washington Post reported in Sunday's editions in a dispatch from Kuwait that two Americans were detained by Iraqi troops. The paper quoted a spokeswoman at the embassy in Kuwait City as saying she did not know where the two Americans were arrested, but that they were detained at a local hotel and are unharmed. In Washington, a State Department spokesman, who asked to remain anonymous, said of the report, ``We are not prepared to confirm this now.'' Saddam had ordered the embassy to close on Friday and to move its functions to the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad. But Howell and his staff remained to keep in touch with the Americans trapped in Kuwait since Iraq invaded the Persian Gulf country Aug. 2. Some 100 U.S. diplomats and dependents fled Kuwait for Iraq late Thursday, arriving in a 33-car caravan after more than 19 hours on the road. According to the Bush administration, their safe passage out of the area was assured by Iraq. But while they were en route, Iraq imposed new regulations prohibiting the departure of diplomats whose embassies had not shut down as ordered by Saddam. This left the diplomats and their families stranded in the Iraqi capital. Late Friday, the Iraqi news agency said the dependents would be permitted to leave. But U.S. officials said they had not been notified. ``The dependents are going to be released,'' al-Mashat said Saturday. In fact, he said, ``some of them will be leaving soon.'' But asked why the diplomats could not join the 60 or so dependents, about 30 of them children, the diplomat said: ``Because they don't have diplomatic status. They are considered ordinary citizens, just like anyone else.'' He then admonished the four reporters questioning him: ``You people should be concerned with the major problem: We are on the brink of catastrophe, unnecessary. Without any reason American lives are being risked. For no reason whatsoever.'' A U.S. official, speaking only on condition of anonymity, said Mack's conversation with al-Mashat focused on the welfare of Americans and other foreign nationals who are in Iraq and Kuwait, ``including their very basic freedom to leave those countries if they desire to do so.''

DOC.HEAD: Four Children Killed When Train Hits Car
DOC.TEXT: Four brothers ranging in age from 1 to 7 were killed Saturday when a freight train going nearly 70 mph smashed into their stalled car as their frantic mother tried to flag the engineer and stop the locomotive. The mother, Leoninia Lendes, 32, of Delano ``got out of the way right at the last moment,'' said police Sgt. Don Callahan. Trapped inside the wreckage were her children, aged 1, 4, 6 and 7. The engineer told police he saw a woman waving and began to brake one block before impact. The Southern Pacific train, traveling nearly 70 mph and pulling about 100 cars had no chance to stop in time, Callahan said. The train carried the auto wreckage for eight blocks before stopping. The railroad crossing arm had dropped behind the 1990 Nissan Sentra, trapping it on the tracks. ``We don't know why her car stalled. She could possibly have panicked,'' Callahan said, adding that the children's mother was treated for emotional distress, he said. Delano, is a small farming community about 30 miles north of Bakersfield. Trains travel through the center of town about once an hour, Callahan said.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Approves Force for Iraqi Embargo; Baghdad Harasses Embassies
LaserPhotos NY11,12,19,20,25,27,29,45; AMM2,7; DOD1,2
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 16th pvs, `Italy's Foreign...' to UPDATE with troops retreating from Canadian Embassy; Pickup 17th, `Iraqi soldiers...'; INSERTS 3 grafs after 27th, `As the...' to ADD reports two more Americans rounded up in Kuwait; Pickup 28th, `Waldheim said...'
DOC.TEXT: The United Nations on Saturday gave the world's navies the right to use force to stop vessels trading with Iraq, and Baghdad cut supplies to some embassies in Kuwait but did not carry out its threat to close them by force. Iraq's U.S. ambassador, meanwhile, said the families of American diplomats who fled Kuwait to Baghdad can leave but that the diplomats will be detained. He also said Iraq will not use force against the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait. In another U.N. initiative, the world body's secretary-general, Javier Perez de Cuellar, announced on Saturday he has invited the Iraqi foreign minister to open urgent talks aimed at resolving the Persian Gulf crisis. Perez de Cuellar said the talks could begin this week in New York or Geneva. But he did not say whether Iraq had accepted the offer. Even as the Security Council took steps to enforce its sanctions, evidence mounted Saturday that the embargo is already squeezing Iraq's citizens. Reports filtering out of Baghdad described panic buying; shortages of cooking oil, flour and fruit; the start of a national rationing program; and house-to-house sweeps by militiamen hunting food hoarders. The official Iraqi News Agency reported that hundreds of Iraqi children gathered outside the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad on Saturday carrying signs complaining that the international trade sanctions are depriving them of milk. The protest was likely to have had official Iraqi sanction. The United States and its allies praised the U.N. Security Council for voting early Saturday to allow military action to uphold the embargo aimed at punishing Iraq for invading Kuwait on Aug. 2. ``Iraq has evaded resolutions of the Security Council and thumbed its nose at all humanity,'' U.S. Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering said following the unanimous vote at the United Nations. ``This has prompted the council to take one of the most important decisions in its history.'' The White House said the vote ``further strengthens the world resolve to force Iraq out of Kuwait.'' Although U.S. warships have been shadowing Iraqi vessels in the Persian Gulf, they have not forced them to stop. President Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, said the United Nations has given the Bush administration a free hand to enforce the economic embargo on Iraq. But he sidestepped a question of how much force America was willing to use. Scowcroft said on Cable News Network that the U.N. action ``means no commerce should go in and out (of Iraq) by sea, and that means that vessels will be stopped and inspected,'' effective immediately. Iraq's U.N. ambassador, Abdul Amir Al-Anbari, immediately denounced the Security Council vote and said it could lead to war. ``This use of force by the United States or any of its allies or puppets will lead inevitably to a number of explosions which will burn all in their path,'' he said at the United Nations in New York. Iraq, meanwhile, carried out its threat to cut supplies to embassies in Kuwait, shutting off power at the Italian, British, Austrian and French missions; power and water at the U.S., East German and Norwegian embassies; and power, water and telephone service at the Japanese mission. Italy's Foreign Ministry said that Iraqi soldiers were knocking down a wall at the French mission in Kuwait in an apparent effort to cut off the water supply there, but France could not immediately confirm the report. But Iraqi troops stationed outside the Canadian Embassy retreated Saturday, Canadian Press news agency said. Iraqi soldiers, some armed with machine guns and mortars, remained outside many embassies in Kuwait City but made no effort to remove diplomats by force, according to reports reaching foreign ministries in several countries. U.S. officials said an electric generator was being used at the U.S. Embassy and that other supplies remained adequate for Ambassador Nathaniel Howell and his staff of about 10 diplomats. Thousands of American troops and dozens of U.S. warships are within striking distance of Iraq and Kuwait, but President Bush has given no indication how he will respond if Iraq attempts to overrun the U.S. embassy. Earlier this week, the United States reduced its staff at the embassy in Kuwait by sending about 100 U.S. diplomats and dependents to Baghdad, where they have been stranded. Iraq's U.S. ambassador said in Washington Saturday that the wives and children of the American diplomats can leave. ``The dependents are going to be released,'' said Mohamed al-Mashat, who had been summoned to the State Department for another U.S. protest. ``Some of them will be leaving soon.'' However, he said the diplomats will be treated ``just like anybody else,'' meaning they will be detained. He said that although Iraq and the United States ``are on the brink of a catastrophe,'' Baghdad is ``not going to use force'' against the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait. Although international law says embassies must remain inviolable even in times of war, Baghdad ordered all embassies in Kuwait to close and threatened to detain as hostages any diplomatic personnel who defy the decree. The many other countries that have refused to close their embassies include Canada, Sweden, Romania, Hungary, Spain, Greece, Bangladesh, Switzerland, Poland, Czechoslovakia and Yugoslavia. Moscow has evacuated its embassy but says it remains technically open. Many governments believe that closing the missions could be interpreted as the first step toward recognition of Iraq's claim of sovereignty over Kuwait. As the embassy standoff continued, 96 Austrian hostages were freed in Iraq, an Austrian official said. Austrian President Kurt Waldheim secured their release in a meeting with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein in Baghdad Saturday. Meanwhile, Japan announced that some of its nationals had been rounded up. And two more Americans were detained by Iraqi troops, the Washington Post quoted a U.S. Embassy spokeswoman in Kuwait city as reporting Saturday. It was not clear when they were detained or where. The spokeswoman said the two were being held at a hotel and were unharmed. A State Department spokesman said of the report: ``We are not prepared to confirm this now.'' Waldheim said later in Amman, Jordan, that he had raised the issue of U.S. and other Western citizens stranded in Iraq and Kuwait with Saddam, but had received no commitments from the Iraqi leader. About 21,000 Westerners, including 3,000 Americans, are being held hostage in Iraq and Kuwait.
DOC.HEAD: Pickup a0627
Train Travels 15 Miles Without Crew, Warning Lights
DOC.TEXT: A runaway freight train traveled more than 15 miles without a crew Saturday and reached speeds of 35 mph before an engineer hopped aboard and brought the train to a halt, police said. Railroad crossing lights, normally activated by train engineers, were not working so police from Brownsville and Cameron County Sheriff's deputies blocked roads along the route with patrol cars. No injuries were reported. Authorities were unsure how the Union Pacific freight train with about 20 cars got loose on the tracks in Brownsville. Railroad officials refused to comment. San Benito is in southern Texas about 250 miles south of San Antonio.

DOC.HEAD: Yacht Overturns in Central Taiwan, Killing 16
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads thruout to ADD British Foreign Office comment, that unclear how many crew aboard; No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A yacht carrying oil company employees on a moon-gazing excursion overturned on a lake in central Taiwan, killing 16 people and leaving at least 36 missing and feared dead, police reported Sunday. In London, a spokesman for Shell Oil Co., whose subsidiary Shell Taiwan Ltd. chartered the yacht, said about 80 employees were aboard. A list provided by the travel agent for the excursion showed 91 joined the trip, police said. Among the missing were three Britons. Police in Nantou, 160 miles southwest of Taipei, said they arrested yacht owner Hsu Ching-hsin for alleged unintentional manslaughter in the accident, which occurred Saturday evening. They said the boat lacked a commercial licence to run on the lake and was overcrowded beyond its 60-person capacity. The boat also violated a ban on yachting after 6:00 p.m. The vessel was chartered for a weekend cruise for Shell Taiwan employees on Sun Moon Lake, a popular resort in Nantou, according to John Crossman, company general manager. Crossman, from Britain, said there were 82 employees and their families, including 30 children, on board the vessel. Alan Jacobs, spokesman for Shell Oil in London said: ``The best information I have is that there were about 80 of our Shell employees and their relatives on a pleasure craft.'' Crossman, who was on the vessel's upper deck, said the boat suddenly overturned as it was turning left about 165 feet from shore and he was tossed overboard. There was no immediate explanation for what caused the boat to tip. Crossman said he was rescued by one of several boats that rushed to the scene. Police said about 34 people swam ashore and several were taken to a hospital, where they were reported in stable condition. It was not clear how many crew were aboard the vessel. The identities of the foreigners aboard were not immediately available, but officials said they included nine Britons, one Australian and 10 Malaysians. Police said those missing included three Britons, identified as Sally Aylwin, 56, Julia Crossman, 40, and Bruce Robson, 48. Their hometowns were not available. It was not immediately clear whether Julia Crossman was related to the Shell Taiwan general manager. The British Foreign Office was unable to confirm that Britons were among the dead or missing. The accident occured on the eve of the Chinese Valentine Day festival when moon-gazing is a traditional part of the celebrations.

DOC.HEAD: TV Studio Goes Off the Air As Police Search for Pizza Robber
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 7th graf pvs, `WLS general...' to UPDATE with search halted, nobody found. Picks up final graf pvs, `The television...
DOC.TEXT: A television station went off the air Saturday night when police evacuated studios to conduct their third search of the day for a possible pizza restaurant robber. After 25 minutes of dead air, Chicago station WLS-TV resumed broadcasting at a jury-rigged studio in the Sears Tower. It issued a special newscast to let viewers know what had happened. The station then went off the air again 15 minutes later as police using scent dogs searched the 13-story studio building. A man thought to be armed with a pistol was seen entering the building Saturday morning not long after a nearby pizza restaurant was robbed, police said. Two daytime searches failed to locate the man, but repeated sightings by station employees prompted the studio evacuation and third search at about 8:30 p.m., Lt. Frank Kehoe said. ``There's no guarantee that this is the guy involved in the robbery,'' Kehoe added. ``It could be just a trespasser.'' WLS general manager Joe Ahearn later said he would not allow employees to return until police were sure it was safe. The station came back on the air at about 1:40 a.m. Sunday reporting in a 10-minute news update that the search failed to find the man. After the update, the station went off the air again. ``We've gone through every cubbyhole as well as the roof and around the satellite dishes,'' said Ahearn, who accompanied police through the building. ``I am absolutely confident that he's not in the building.'' The television station is owned and operated by ABC. WLS broadcasts are seen in eight counties in northern Illinois, two in northwestern Indiana and two in southern Wisconsin.

DOC.HEAD: Overloaded Tourist Boat Overturns, Killing at Least 19
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING to CORRECT overline
DOC.TEXT: An overloaded tourist boat carrying oil company employees on a moon-gazing cruise overturned on a lake in central Taiwan, killing 19 people and leaving at least 33 missing, police said Sunday. In London, a spokesman for Shell Oil Co., whose subsidiary Shell Taiwan Ltd. chartered the boat, said about 80 employees were aboard. A list provided by the travel agent for the excursion showed 91 joined the trip, police said. A Shell Taiwan official said four Britons were among those killed in the accident on Sun Moon Lake late Saturday, eve of the Chinese Valentine day festival. Moon-gazing is a traditional part of the celebrations. Police said they arrested yacht owner Hsu Ching-hsin for alleged unintentional manslaughter in the accident. The boat lacked a license to operate on the lake and was packed beyond its 60-person capacity, they said. The vessel had been chartered for a weekend cruise for employees on the lake in Nantou, 160 miles southwest of Taipei, according to Johnathan Crossman, general manager of Shell Taiwan. About 200 rescuers, including divers, searched the lake throughout Saturday night and Sunday, Police said. Crossman, 44, from Britain, said there were 82 employees and their families, including 30 children, aboard the vessel. Alan Jacobs, spokesman for Shell Oil Co. in London said: ``The best information I have is that there were about 80 of our Shell employees and their relatives on a pleasure craft.'' Crossman, who was on the vessel's upper deck, said the boat suddenly capsized as it turned to the left about 50 yards from shore and he was tossed overboard. Newspapers quoted survivors as saying strong winds overturned the boat. Crossman and his 7-year-old daughter, Nicola, were rescued by boats that rushed to the scene, but his wife, Julia, 40, and a son, Robert, 6, were missing, Shell official Tseng Tung-shin said. Tseng said Sally Aylwin, 46, wife of Shell executive Charles Aylwin was killed and another Shell executive from Britain, Bruce Robson, 48, was missing. Aylwin and his two teen-age children were rescued. Crossman _ who was transferred to Taiwan last November _ and Aylwin were believed from London, but Robson's hometown was not immediately known, Tseng said. Police said about 34 people swam ashore and several were taken to a hospital, where they were reported in stable condition. It was not immediately clear how many crew members were aboard the vessel. Officials said foreigners aboard included nine Britons, one Australian and 10 Malaysians.

DOC.HEAD: 178 Miners Trapped, 8 Bodies Recovered
DOC.TEXT: An underground explosion killed at least eight coal miners early Sunday and trapped 178, the Tanjug news agency reported. The blast occurred at the Dobrnja-Jug pit of the Kreka mine, located 90 miles west of Belgrade. Eight bodies were recovered, and two miners were pulled out alive, Tanjug reported. It said 188 miners were in the shaft at the time of the explosion. The blast likely was caused by coal dust, methane gas, or a combination of the two, Tanjug said. Coal dust is explosive under certain conditions. There was no immediate information on how many of the trapped miners might have been killed by the blast, or how deep they were in the shaft. No further details were available immediately.

DOC.HEAD: 55 U.S. Dependents From U.S. Embassy in Kuwait Leave Baghdad
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads withy 5 grafs to UPDATE with embassy saying dependents have left Baghdad en route to Turkey. Pickup 6th, `Earlier this...'
DOC.TEXT: About 55 dependents of American diplomats who were stranded for several days in Baghdad after fleeing Kuwait left the Iraqi capital on Sunday for Turkey, the U.S. Embassy here said. Embassy spokeswoman Carole Lee Heileman said the Americans left Baghdad early Sunday morning in a 13-car convoy for the Turkey-Iraqi border. Ms. Heileman said the group was expected to arrive at Turkey's Habur border post sometime in the afternoon or evening. From there they will be taken by bus to the southern Turkish city of Diyarbakir and will be flown out of Turkey sometime Monday, she said. She said the 55 were all dependents of U.S. personnel who had been stationed in the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait. ``An additional 54 or 55 personnel, mostly men, who had been stationed in Kuwait are still in Baghdad and we have not secured their release,'' Ms. Heileman said. Earlier this week, Iraq gave a Friday deadline for nations to close their embassies in Kuwait, claiming its oil-rich neighbor as part of Iraqi territory. Iraq annexed Kuwait six days after its Aug. 2 invasion of the emirate. But the United States, most European nations and many other countries have refused to close their embassies in Kuwait city, instead reducing personnel there to a minimum. The U.S. Embassy sent about 100 diplomats and their dependents to Baghdad, where they were stranded when Iraqi President Saddam Hussein reversed an earlier promise and refused to let them leave. But on Saturday, Iraq's U.S. ambassador said in Washington that the wives and children of the American diplomats would be allowed to leave. ``The dependents are going to be released,'' said Mohamed al-Mashat, who had been summoned to the State Department for another U.S. protest. ``Some of them will be leaving soon.'' However, he said the diplomats will be treated ``just like anybody else,'' meaning they will be detained. He said that although Iraq and the United States ``are on the brink of a catastrophe,'' Baghdad is ``not going to use force'' against the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait. Iraqi troops have surrounded several embassies in Kuwait City, cutting off water and electricity to many. Iraq had initially said it would not allow any of the party of 100 leave baghdad until the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait was closed. In all, about 21,000 foreigners have been caught in Iraq and Kuwait, including 3,000 Americans. Some were distributed among Iraqi strategic sites for use as human shields to deter any U.S. attack.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Refugees Can Escape Through Iran, Tehran Radio Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE that Syria promised Saturday to open its border, more on border crossings in Iran. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Iran's foreign minister said Sunday that foreigners fleeing Iraq and Kuwait can do so through Iran, according to Tehran radio. The report came after Jordan and Turkey complained that they are overburned by thousands of refugees and said they may have to close their borders. Syria, Iraq's main Arab rival, announced on Saturday that it will allow foreigners to cross the Syrian border with Iraq. Most of the people who have fled Iraq and Kuwait since Baghdad invaded its oil-rich neighbor on Aug. 2 have entered Jordan, forcing it to feed and shelter them until they can afford to continue on to their home countries. Iran has condemned the invasion of Kuwait and said it will enforce an international trade embargo against Iraq. But Iran also recently settled disputes over territory and prisoners of war left unsettled by its long war with Iraq, and that allowed Iraq to transfer thousands of troops from the Iranian border and move them to occupied Kuwait. The Tehran radio broadcast, monitored in Nicosia, quoted Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati as saying that for humanitarian reasons ``Iran agrees to foreign evacuees from Iraq and Kuwait transiting in its territory.'' Iran shares a 730-mile-long border with Iraq. Velayati agreed to let foreigners leave through Iran after Philippines Foreign Minister Raul Manglapus, who is visiting Tehran, asked that thousands of his countrymen trapped in Iraq and Kuwait be allowed to cross into Iran. Velayati did not specify if Tehran's offer included only Asians, or whether thousands of Western hostages in Iraq will be able to cross the border too. Tensions between Iran and Iraq have lessened since Baghdad settled a border dispute with Tehran last month, pulled out troops from occupied Iranian territory and initiated an exchange of prisoners of war. However, the border is still heavily fortified on both sides, and foreigners will likely be allowed to cross only at certain points. About 50,000 Iranians living in Kuwait have returned home through the Iran-Iraq border, and hundreds more continue to stream in every day. Food, water and a place to sleep are provided for the refugees, according to the Tehran radio report.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi President Invites U.N. Chief to Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to CORRECT that Perez de Cuellar invited the Iraqi foreign minister, not Saddam, ADD more on news conference. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar has invited Iraq to open talks aimed at resolving the Persian Gulf crisis, and President Saddam Hussein has invited the U.N. chief to visit Iraq. The developments offered the first glimmer of hope that the crisis caused by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 could be solved by negotiations. However, the United States has repeatedly said no peace talks are possible until Iraq withdraws its troops from Kuwait, which Baghdad has refused to do. On Saturday, Perez de Cuellar invited the Iraqi foreign minister to open peace talks. Perez de Cuellar, who issued his statement while traveling in Bogota, Colombia, said the talks could begin this week in New York or Geneva, but he did not say whether Iraq had accepted the offer. In Baghdad on Saturday, Saddam was asked by reporters traveling with Austrian President Kurt Waldheim, whether he would agree to meet with the United Nations secretary-general in Iraq. ``Of course,'' Saddam replied, ``the U.N. secretary-general is always welcome.'' Although Saddam did not mention Perez de Cuellar by name, it was assumed he was extending the invitation to him. Perez de Cuellar called for peace talks hours after the U.N. Security Council authorized the use of military force to uphold the trade embargo imposed on Iraq in a bid to force it to withdraw from Kuwait. ``I believe that after the resolutions adopted by the Security Council, the time has come for the secretary-general to begin diplomatic efforts to alleviate the present crisis in the gulf in all aspects, through the process of dialogue,'' Perez de Cuellar said. In Kennebunkport, Maine, White House spokesman Roman Popadiuk said Saturday he had not heard about Perez de Cuellar's proposal but that Washington welcomes a ``discussion by all U.N. members in the context of the complete and immediate and unconditional withdrawal'' of Iraqi forces from Kuwait. The Saddam news conference, which was broadcast by Cable News Netrowk, came at the end of a one-day visit by Waldheim, who flew out of Baghdad with 100 Austrian nationals who had been stranded in the country. About 3,000 Americans and 4,500 Britons remain stranded in Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Sikh Gunmen Kill Family of Policeman, Eight Others in Punjab
DOC.TEXT: Sikh gunmen raided the home of a police interrogator in Punjab and killed four members of his family, police said Sunday. Elsewhere in the state, eight deaths were blamed on Sikh militants who are leading a violent campaign for an independent homeland in the rich farming state, news reports said. The killings brought the number of deaths blamed on the militants in the Punjab this year to 1,795. The militants say Sikhs are discriminated against by the majority Hindus. Sikhs make up two percent of India's 880 million people, but they are in slight majority in Punjab. Hindus are 82 percent nationwide. About half a dozen militants burst into the home of Constable Dalbir Singh near Tarn Taran late Saturday, said area police chief Narinder Pal Singh. The gunmen shot and killed the policeman's 50-year-old mother and three daughters. The other deaths occurred across the state in separate incidents on Saturday, United News of India reported.

DOC.HEAD: Paper Prints Norway's First Major Sunday Edition in 71 Years
DOC.TEXT: A newspaper came out with Norway's first national Sunday edition since 1919, when typographers and other workers stopped the presses by refusing to work on the Sabbath. Dagbladet, one of the country's top three newspapers, kept its Sunday edition secret until Saturday night, calling it a ``guerrilla attack'' on its rivals, the Oslo newspapers Verdens Gang and Aftenposten. The Oslo tabloid's editorial said changes in labor laws, which used to severely limit working on Sundays, made it possible to resume printing seven editions a week after a break of 71 years. About 225,000 copies of the 48-page newspaper were distributed nationwide. The state radio network NRK predicted a rush of other Sunday newspapers.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Mideast Force Approaches 60,000 Troops; More Marines Expected
DOC.TEXT: Roughly 60,000 American soldiers, airmen and sailors have moved to battle stations in the Persian Gulf since President Bush ordered U.S. firepower into the area to thwart Iraq's Saddam Hussein, sources say. In addition to the massive troop movement, the Pentagon has built a virtual armada in the region's seas and rushed in hundreds of fighter jets and support aircraft. The deployment, the largest since the Vietnam War, is far from complete. Within a few weeks, about 45,000 Marines are expected to have arrived in the area. By then the total U.S. combat force in the region may number well over 100,000, military sources said last week. The final elements of the 7th Marine Expeditionary Brigade were arriving in Saudi Arabia over the weekend after a 7,000-mile flight from their home base at Twentynine Palms, Calif., and the 1st Marine Expeditionary Brigade was heading for the gulf from its home base at Kaneohe Bay, Hawaii, one source said. A third Marine unit, the 4th Marine Expeditionary Brigade from Camp Lejeune, N.C., was preparing for deployment but was not expected to arrive for at least another two weeks. Over the past week, the Bush administration added significantly to not only the U.S. ground forces in Saudi Arabia but also the air and sea power in the area, including: _A squadron of 22 F-117A stealth fighter-bombers. The radar-evading planes, on their first overseas deployment, are specially designed to operate at night. They can slip deep behind enemy lines to lead an offensive strike on vital targets. _The aircraft carrier USS Saratoga arrived in the Red Sea by way of the Suez Canal. It is accompanied by the Aegis missile cruiser Philippine Sea and the missile cruiser Biddle. It is to be joined soon by three other members of its battle group, the missile destroyer Sampson and frigates Elmer Montgomery and Thomas C. Hart. The aircraft carrier USS Eisenhower, which had been on patrol in the Red Sea, headed back into the Mediterranean. _The aviation brigade of the 101st Airborne Division, an air assault unit based at Fort Campbell, Ky., began arriving in the Saudi desert. It is armed with Apache helicopters, the backbone of the Army's tank-killing arsenal. The aircraft are equipped with laser-guided missiles that can hit moving targets at night. _The first deployments of U.S. forces from NATO bases in Europe. Elements of the U.S. Army Europe's 7th Medical Command, based in West Germany, headed for Saudi Arabia, as did C-130E Hercules transport airplanes of the 435th Tactical Airlift Wing from West Germany. Also, the Strategic Air Command acknowledged Saturday that B-52 bombers were dispatched overseas two weeks ago from two undisclosed U.S. air bases. Bush last week authorized the Pentagon to call up military reserves for the first time in 20 years. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney on Thursday approved plans to activate as many as 46,700 members of the National Guard and armed forces reserves, and the first call-ups came Friday. Cheney said nearly 10,000 reserves would be called to active duty by the end of August and the total would reach 46,700 by Oct. 1. Most of the reserves are to be sent to the Arabian peninsula. Others will fill vacancies left by U.S. troops deploying to the Middle East from the United States or Europe. One of the least publicized features of the enormous mobilization of U.S. forces is the Marine Corps operation. For years the Marines have organized what they call Marine Prepositioned Ships at three strategic points on the globe: along the Atlantic Coast, near Diego Garcia in the Indian Ocean and near Guam. The idea is that in time of crisis, any or all of these three units _ each with four or five ships _ could move quickly into an area of conflict with enough firepower and supplies to last 30 days. The Marine Prepositioned Ships from Diego Garcia and Guam were among the first forces to get the word to head for Saudi Arabia. The first group took just six days to get there. ``It's been a very substantial projection of combat force, and this is important: both air and ground,'' said Marine Corps Lt. Col. Stuart Wagner, a Pentagon spokesman. Among the weapons each Marine expeditionary brigade brings to the field are M-1 tanks, F@A-18 attack aircraft, 115mm howitzers and A-6E ground attack airplanes. Some Army airborne units were deployed quickly to Saudi Arabia, but they were unable to bring as much firepower and supplies with them as the Marines, which are virtually self-sustaining in food, water, fuel, trucks, weapons and ammunition.

DOC.HEAD: Public Relations Ploys of Bush, Saddam Backfire
With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Rodger in 6th graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein are both learning that cultivating the right image through television can be a tricky business. Saddam's lesson came in his failed attempt to ease international fears about the safety of Western hostages in Iraq and Kuwait. Instead, he provoked outrage by releasing a videotape that showed him patting the heads of cringing British boys. The relentlessly vacationing Bush set out to show that the Persian Gulf crisis wasn't holding him hostage in the White House. But he has faced criticism that his golf-playing and motorboating in Kennebunkport, Maine, were inappropriate when U.S. soldiers were preparing for war along the Kuwaiti-Saudi border. ``Saddam Hussein must have figured that these tapes would play wonderfully all over the world,'' said Philip Robbins, chairman of the journalism department at George Washington University. ``The reaction ... is almost completely contrary to that,'' Robbins said. If it was meant to change world opinion, ``I think it's failed miserably.'' ``It's pretty clear that this was total theatrics that they had put together to win the sympathy of some people somewhere,'' said Rodger Streitmatter, an American University specialist in presidential public relations. ``But,'' he added, ``it certainly is not going to convince very many Americans that this is a humanitarian undertaking.'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater also denounced Saddam's venture into video. ``The Iraqi film of Saddam Hussein posing with British hostages shows the cynical and inhumane view that he holds for human life,'' Fitzwater said. ``To hold men, women and children up for viewing as targets for destruction is sick beyond expression. ``It only serves to confirm and justify the world condemnation of Iraq's aggressive ambitions.'' Bush's problems stem from his determination to avoid appearing to be a hostage in the White House of the Middle East situation. President Jimmy Carter was accused of that after the Iranian siege of the U.S. Embassy in Tehran in 1979 and the taking of American hostages. Bush proceeded with vacation plans even as he ordered the deployment of U.S. forces to the Gulf region and continued frequent telephone contact with other world leaders. ``Reasonably thinking people would realize that this man continues to be in touch with what's going on in the world and with communication the way it is today could react to anything that happened,'' said Streitmatter. ``But ... we tend to remember more what we see than what we hear, and what we see is him playing golf,'' he said. ``Here we have these images of these troops preparing to go off to (potential) combat and leaving their families behind, juxtaposed against these images of our president playing golf.'' Robbins said Bush apparently was trying ``to present a picture of the presidency being able to handle the situation without anything abnormal taking place, so everybody should stay calm, cool and collected. But I don't think it's worked that way.'' ``I think most of the public when they see ... the troops going to Saudi Arabia and the reservists being called up and the discomfort, the downright inconvenience and the possible fate that all of these service people are meeting, I don't think they like it very much,'' Robbins said. ``I think it's going to turn out to be a public-relations disaster, not just a mistake.'' Streitmatter, noting that Bush's golfing had sparked criticism from women demonstrators in Jordan, said international television added a further dimension to the problem. ``At a time when we're dealing an international crisis and we need some of these other nations dealing with this crisis with us, it does make sense for the White House to be more sensitive to cultural differences,'' he said. Stephen Hess of the Brookings Institution, a former adviser to Democratic and Republican presidents, said, however, that Bush's public-relations mistake was only ``of the most modest sort.'' ``It really isn't that troubling out in the hinterlands. That's what we're finding out,'' Hess said. ``George Bush is notably not a frivolous man,'' he said. ``Nobody thinks that he isn't paying proper attention. Sure he shouldn't have answered reporters' questions while he was on the golf links and maybe they should have made greater efforts to pretend that presidents are working night and day while they're on vacation. But ... George Bush is doing what a president is supposed to be doing.'' Streitmatter said long-term damage from Bush's image problems would occur only if a disaster _ such as a number of soldiers being killed _ were seen to coincide with his playing golf. ``This sort of thing is so ephemeral that there's no way it's going to stick to the ribs,'' said Hess. ``The president comes back to Washington in another 10 days and that's the end of this as an issue.'' What's really hurting him is not so much the fact that he's on vacation, but all we ever seem to see is him on vacation.''

DOC.HEAD: Impending End of a Nation Creates Mixed Feelings
DOC.TEXT: East Germany is about to disappear, to be swallowed up by its rich western neighbor, and the universal enthusiasm of a few months ago has waned. Polls say the vast majority of East Germans favor unification, which is barely a month away. But appearances don't always reinforce that conclusion. The ``We are one people'' banners that hung from trees, factories and homes during the pro-unity frenzy of early 1990 are gone. There are no cheering crowds and no convoys of motorists blasting their horns in anticipation of full unification on Oct. 3. Reality has set in, especially since the economic merger officially began in July. The issue foremost in the minds of East Germans is how to tackle the huge challenges facing them as their crumbling economy is absorbed by West Germany. Some show a decided lack of eagerness for unity, especially in Leipzig, birthplace of the uprising that ended 40 years of Stalinist rule less than a year ago. ``Maybe the GDR (East Germany) could have survived as a newly democratized country,'' said Maria Chudoba, who tends bar at the Cappuccino cafe in Leipzig. ``But now it's too late to turn back.'' Heinz Weisse, 74, and his 70-year-old wife, Gertrud, loading bales of hay onto a cart outside Weimar, said they wouldn't have minded seeing East Germany continue as a democracy. ``We're happy about unity, but it was not a necessary development,'' said Weisse, a retired hairdresser. ``There's a good side and bad side to everything.'' He said he and his wife had a relatively good life even under communism and, as pensioners, had been allowed to travel outside the country. ``We had our little house here, and we were born here, so we always came back,'' Weisse said. Most East Germans seem to see unification as their only salvation, but have come to realize it will not be an overnight cure for such problems as the high unemployment brought on by the July 1 economic union. ``We had our celebrations last year when the Berlin Wall came down,'' said Gisela Oswald, a 63-year-old retired opera singer in Weimar, an East German cultural center. ``We're glad unity is coming, but we've got to get to work now on some important problems, like putting the economy in order.'' East German cities are decaying, the bottom has dropped out of industrial production and unemployment is soaring. Most of East Germany's problems require money in huge amounts. Leipzig has a desperate housing shortage, crumbling public and commercial buildings and an antiquated sewerage system that has become a health hazard. Unification and the resulting West German funds undoubtedly will help solve the economic problems over the next few years, but also will introduce problems new to East Germany. ``Prostitution will come with the joblessness because people need money,'' said Peter Fernau, chief of detectives in Bitterfeld, an industrial city. ``We're also worried about heroin and the possible appearance of criminal gangs. There will be totally new dimensions to crime.'' Several aspects of life will change after unity. West Germany's legal system will be extended to the East, bringing in an entirely new code of laws. ``My officers are going to have to learn, learn, learn,'' Fernau said. Many East Germans fear West Germans will make all the decisions about their future. A recent poll by the West German magazine Stern indicated 88 percent of East Germans support unification, but 70 percent were disappointed by how it has been managed. The process has been largely orchestrated by Helmut Kohl, West Germany's chancellor. With the two Germanys united, East Germans will find themselves in stiff competition with West Germans jobs and business opportunities. They worry about coping. ``We never learned to persist in the face of adversity because, in the old system, that was of no use,'' said Ms. Oswald, the opera singer. ``This is something we must learn. ``But we also have many good qualities. We tend to be very close-knit and helpful to each other, and that's something we don't want to lose,'' she said. Peter Heyroth, Lutheran pastor in Bitterfeld, said the way unity has been managed is demoralizing many people. ``They see the trucks rumbling into town at 6 a.m. with goods from West Germany, while goods made in this country go unsold,'' he said. ``They see prices climbing, and they feel like their job training was worthless.'' In the small city of Saalfeld, on the eastern edge of the Thuringian forest, a former member of the disbanded Communist secret police pondered his future. He has a new job, but things aren't going well. ``People hoot at me behind my back,'' he said. ``It's really very difficult.'' ``I was never involved in any heavy intelligence, just checking passports and that kind of thing, but I'm ashamed of the corrupt government we supported,'' said the former agent, who asked that his name not be used. Then, seeming to speak for many East Germans, he said: ``Sure, mistakes were made during the Communist period, but should four decades of our past really be flushed down the sewer?''

DOC.HEAD: Ragtag Tamil Rebel Force Challenges Sri Lanka's Army
DOC.TEXT: The barefoot rifle-toting guerrillas occupying this eastern village hardly seem a match for the crisply uniformed government soldiers down the road with well-oiled machine guns. But here and elsewhere in Sri Lanka, the Tamil Tiger rebels _ many of them only teen-agers _ are engaging the army in a long and savage civil war. ``Step by step we will defeat the army,'' said a Tiger commander who has taken the name Newton. That seems unlikely, in the view of observers and Western diplomats. But the army also seems incapable of beating the ragtag guerrillas. In the north, the government launched a major offensive last week to relieve Jaffna Fort, a 300-year-old colonial outpost besieged by the rebels for 10 weeks. After initial gains, the advance bogged down under heavy rebel mortar fire and machine-gun fusillades from bunkers, the government said. On Sunday, military officials said, troops overran the guerrillas after a three-hour battle on Mandativu Island, a stepping stone to the star-shaped fortress. But army troops have failed to meet their aim of reaching the trapped 250-man garrison in the fort, the government's strongest outpost on the rebel-controlled Jaffna Peninsula. On the eastern front, the guerrillas have once again yielded the main towns and most of the roads to the army. They have faded into the jungles and the villages from where they have launched hit-and-run raids and mined roads for the past seven years. Newton, asked about his tactical objectives in the east, had a simple answer. ``We are going to kill a large number of army,'' he said. Newton and two other Tiger commanders, known as Karikalan and Nithi, spoke in a bare room in the dusty village of Karadiyanaru, on the main road leading to Batticaloa, 170 miles southeast of Jaffna. Earlier, government officials had earlier claimed all three had been killed. The rebels were contacted by walkie-talkie from a checkpoint manned by a dozen barefoot teen-agers who wore wore fatigue shirts and ammunition belts, stuffed with rifle clips, grenades and a toothbrush _ for cleaning weapons. The civil war erupted in 1983 over Tamil complaints that they were suppressed by the Sinhalese, who comprise 75 percent of the population and control the government. Tamils make up 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people. The Tigers, who demand independence for their ethnic minority, are the only Tamil group continuing the fight. Others gave up their weapons in 1987 and agreed to negotiate for an autonomous region in the north and east. After a 13-month cease-fire, the Tigers resumed the war on June 11, by storming 30 police and army barracks in the east. Villagers in Karadiyanaru appeared unhappy over the presence of the rebels. Food is scarce, commerce has stopped and the area is virtually cut off from the rest of the region. Army patrols occasionally come through, firing into roadside homes. ``All the poor people in this area get no help from the government or from anyone else,'' said one village elder. An army officer commanding a checkpoint 12 miles to the west of the village claimed only about 100 Tigers were scattered in the bush, and the rest had fled to the north. The army checkpoint had four small armored vehicles, and the troops looked sharp and well-trained. Newton, asked whether his forces were retreating, only laughed. About 15 Tigers were seen in and near the village. The Tigers' heaviest weapons are mortars, and most equipment is stolen or stripped from the corpses of army casualties. Newton proudly displayed a homemade mortar from a secret armory. The Liberation Tigers for Tamil Eelam grew out of a student movement in the Jaffna area in the 1970s and emerged into the open as a guerrilla force in 1983. The group is led by Veluppillai Prabhakaran, a school dropout who catapulted to the group's leadership when he assassinated the mayor of Jaffna in 1975. Prabhakaran demands absolute discipline. His forces are forbidden to smoke or drink. He approves every major operation, according to a source close to the Tigers. Western diplomats believe a political settlement is the only answer to the war, but it may be a long time in coming. ``The government has to knock back the Tigers a bit, militarily,'' said one diplomat who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``They can't defeat the Tigers or wipe them out,'' the diplomat said. ``There will have to be a stalemate for long enough for the war fever to wear off.''

DOC.HEAD: VOA Says Iraq Jamming Its Arabic Broadcasts To Persian Gulf
With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq has jammed the Voice of America's Arabic language broadcasts since the Persian Gulf crisis began, but VOA says the radio programs still can be heard. In a message sent to U.S. embassies in the gulf region last week, the agency said it was possible to overcome the Iraqi jamming in several ways. Embassies were urged to advise listeners who did not hear the VOA broadcasts on the usual frequency to tune around in the same shortwave band because the frequency might have been changed to avoid jamming. Also, the message said, the Arabic broadcasts emanate from relay stations that are west of Iraq and thus are in daylight while the Iraqi jamming stations are in darkness. Since the stations still in daylight can use higher frequencies, listeners were advised to tune to the highest frequency after sunset. Voice of America said also that its Arabic language broadcasts to North Africa generally are not jammed and can be heard in the Gulf region, although not as well as those directed toward the Middle East. ``Listen in different locations, even within the same house or apartment,'' the message said. ``Shortwave reception can differ greatly from within the same room. One location may favor VOA more than the jamming signal.'' VOA spokeswoman Judy Jamison said Iraq had not previously jammed the broadcasts, but began doing so within a few days after its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, utilizing ``a definite warbling sound.'' Despite the jamming, Ms. Jamison said, ``a determined listener'' can hear the broadcasts. VOA's English language broadcasts are not jammed, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Who's That Crouching Next to the Pianist? Hey, It's Elmer Booze!
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Elmer Booze strides onto the concert stage for another virtuoso performance, but nobody applauds. He shares the spotlight but never takes a bow. His name doesn't even appear in the program. So what? The guy spends most of the evening staring at the sheet music and wetting his thumb and forefinger. Big deal. Any pianist, though, will say that Elmer Booze really is a big deal. He is a professional page turner, one of the most indispensable _ and most anonymous _ figures in the musical world. Booze, 57, a small, soft-spoken man who wears gold-rimmed glasses, has turned the pages of musical scores for Aaron Copland, Rudolf Serkin, Andre Watts, Leon Fleisher and Bella Davidovich and hundreds of other musicians for nearly a quarter-century. He turned pages for opera singer Leontyne Price's accompanist at a White House recital for President Carter. He's been a consultant and resident page turner for the annual summer Newport (R.I.) Music Festival for the past 14 years. He's a regular at concert series at the National Gallery of Art, the Canadian Embassy, the Kennedy Center and the Library of Congress in Washington. He has flown to New York and London to sit at the elbow of concert pianists who insisted that only Elmer Booze would do. An accomplished pianist himself, with music degrees from two universities, Booze is content to labor in the shadows of the keyboard giants. A colleague at the Library of Congress, where Booze works during the day as a senior reference librarian in the music division, proudly calls him ``a world-renowned page turner.'' Booze modestly dismisses such extravagant praise. ``For me, it's a job that anybody can do,'' he said. ``But apparently that's not entirely true. I've talked to pianists who say they can't turn pages. It makes them very nervous.'' By contrast, Booze sits on the edge of his chair with unflappable ease as the pianist struggles through stormy fortissimos and crashing arpeggios. ``Pianists want someone with them in their greatest moment of need, when they've gotten to the last note on the page,'' he said. That's the moment when Booze shifts into a low crouch and, with a lightning thrust of the arm, flips to the next page and returns to his seat. His movements are so unobtrusive that one pianist calls him ``the ghost.'' A good page turner must be skilled in reading a musical score, Booze says, and a rehearsal is helpful to become familiar with the pianist's eccentricities. Does he memorize the score? (Chamber music is rarely played from memory, Booze says.) Are the pianist's jerks and nods a signal to turn the page, or is he simply getting carried away with the music? Are the pages old and brittle? Do they stick together? Onstage, he says, a page turner should keep his eyes on the music and maintain ``a certain decorum'' to put the pianist at ease. ``If there's panic in your eyes, you can believe the pianist will panic, too,'' he said. ``The last thing he needs is a spastic page turner.'' Despite the page turner's best efforts, disasters do happen. Booze recalls the nightmarish evening of the missing paper clip. His pianist had promised in the dressing room of the Kennedy Center Concert Hall to insert a paper clip in the score of a devilishly complex work by Franz Liszt for two pianos. At the point when Booze was supposed to turn back 20 pages for a repeat in the second movement, the paper clip wasn't there. ``It was something to behold,'' he said. ``He was going like a bat out of hell. His arms were in my way and mine were in his, trying to find the exact page. Both pianists stopped playing, and the whole thing came to a screeching halt. It was not a good show.'' Booze has left his tuxedo jacket unbuttoned during concerts ever since he rose from his chair to turn a page for Aaron Copland and a button popped onto the keyboard while the composer was performing at the Library of Congress. Booze turned another anxious moment into a tour de force that garnered the first and only ovation he has ever received from an audience. When he and a pianist took their seats at the Newport festival, they discovered that the piano's music rack had been removed and was nowhere to be found. So Booze became a human music rack, holding up photocopies of each page of the score. When the piece was finished, the festival president leaped to her feet. ``Let's all clap for Elmer,'' she shouted, and the page turner shyly emerged from the shadows to accept his acclaim.

DOC.HEAD: Fires Under Control After Five Days
DOC.TEXT: Firefighters and soldiers worked Sunday to extinguish fires that raged for five days near the Mediterranean cities of Toulon and Nice. One firefighter has died and one was seriously hurt battling the blazes. The fire near Toulon in the southern Var region, which started Tuesday, was fanned by strong mistral winds. It destroyed up to 34,600 acres of brush and pine forest before being brought under control, making it one of the area's biggest single fires, officials said. On Sunday, planes and helicopters were dumping water over pockets of flames and smoldering brush. A smaller fire near Nice, at the eastern end of the French Riviera, also was nearly extinguished Sunday, five days after it began. Police sources said that fire, which destroyed 1,485 acres of Mediterranean pine, might have been arson. A volunteer firefighter was killed Wednesday fighting the blaze near Nice when his truck overturned, and on Friday, a fireman was seriously injured in the Var region when his vehicle plunged into a ravine.

DOC.HEAD: Glimmers of Hope for Philly Courts, Prisons
With AM-Out of Jails, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The mayor calls courtrooms in this city ``a bastion of inefficiency,'' but justice no longer will be delayed if a fast-track program continues to cut into heavy courtroom backlogs, supporters say. Expected to cut a 12,200-case backlog by 41 percent this year, it's a glimmer of hope for city courts, police and prisons, which a blue-ribbon task force characterized earlier this year as at ``the edge of a precipice.'' Optimism has been buoyed in some quarters by four reports this year that recommended a new courthouse, more prison cells, a professional court administrator and other changes. ``I see light,'' said A. Leo Levin, a University of Pennsylvania law professor and chairman of the 16-member Philadelphia Criminal Justice Task Force that produced one of the reports. ``I refuse to see the absence of light.'' Richard F. Moore, projects management coordinator for the city's Justice Facilities and System Improvement Strategy program, said that when the reports appeared, ``everybody simply condemned everybody's report.'' ``However, it seemed that once everybody got all that out of their system, everybody started reading these reports,'' he said. ``Things that we wrote started popping up in various proposed solutions.'' Skeptics say Philadelphia's justice system is so mired in politics it can never change. ``The fact is that government in Philadelphia, historically and to some extent today, operates in a culture of nepotism, favoritism and corruption,'' said Gerald M. Caplan, a law professor at George Washington University and staff director for a 1987 report on the Philadelphia Police Department. The courts have been engaged in a running battle with city government over construction of a new courthouse and who should pay the costs of court staff. ``Our courts, which should serve as a bulwark of equity, are instead a mecca of patronage,'' Mayor W. Wilson Goode said last week. ``They should stand as a monument of progress, but are instead a bastion of inefficiency.'' He has called for sweeping court reforms before the courthouse is built. An audit conducted as part of a judges' lawsuit seeking more city funds concluded the courts had enough money ``to perform their constitutional mission,'' but said more money could cut backlogs. ``The delays now tolerated ... are excessive by any standard,'' the audit said. Common Pleas Court had a 10-month backlog of criminal cases and a 27-month backlog of civil cases at the time. The audit urged more accountability for judges and less control by lawyers of the pace of proceedings. Yet a cooperative effort begun Jan. 2 by prosecutors, public defenders and Common Pleas Court drew praise in the audit and other reports. It was intended to speed the processing of less serious felonies such as retail theft, auto theft, forgery and arson. The backlog is projected to fall to 7,263 by Dec. 31 from 12,199 at the end of last year, according to the district attorney's office. At that rate, the backlog would be gone by April 1992. The program allows defendants to enter guilty pleas earlier in the court process than previously, to combine pleas if facing more than one charge and to reach trial sooner if they plead innocent. It will be attempted with major felonies come autumn. ``This program benefits everyone by eliminating unnecessary postponements and by providing trial listings only to those cases which cannot be disposed through appropriate plea arrangements,'' District Attorney Ronald D. Castille said. Another bright spot may be found in plans to expand a 125-inmate holding cell area on the seventh floor of City Hall. An average of 280 prisoners are jammed daily behind Plexiglas panels to await court hearings. ``It looks like a way station to hell when you see the bodies lined up in there,'' said Allen M. Hornblum, chief of staff since May for the Sheriff's Department. By December, several nearby offices now used for inmate psychiatric exams will be converted into more holding cells, he said. ``It will benefit the people we put in the cells as well as the deputies who guard them,'' Hornblum said. ``It's gotten to the point where something very explosive could happen that would affect public safety in a very serious way.'' More crowding exists in the city's four prisons, which have a federal court cap on population of 3,750 but typically have 5,000 to 5,200 inmates. The city was ordered in July to pay $20,000 in fines a day because of its failure to add more guards, nurses and social workers and meet other conditions required under a separate lawsuit. Prisons Commissioner J. Patrick Gallagher, who was hired in 1989, sees construction of 500 new cells this fall as the beginning of the rehabilitation and replacement of prison buildings dating from 1893.

DOC.HEAD: Ambassasor's Wife Says He Has Become Symbol Of Hope
With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The wife of Ambassador W. Nathaniel Howell, who is trapped in the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait, says her husband has become a symbol of peace and hope for Americans and foreigners held hostage by Saddam Hussein. Margie Saunders Howell said in an interview at her Charlottesville home Saturday that she feared for her husband's safety. But she said he had no choice but to stay at the American mission after Saddam ordered embassy personnel to Baghdad and the mission closed. She has faith that Howell can stand up to Iraqi pressure. Howell and 10 others remained at the besieged embassy Sunday, two days after Iraqi troops surrounded it, cutting off electricity and water. Marine embassy guards were among personnel sent to Baghdad, the State Department said. The United States, Canada, Japan, Bangladesh, Switzerland, Austria, Poland, Czechoslovakia, Yugoslavia and the 12 European Community nations were among those who announced they would defy the Iraqi order to shut down. ``He knows that things could go badly, because there's nothing between him and the Iraqis,'' Mrs. Howell said. ``But his presence there is not only a sign to Iraq that we don't agree with their actions, it's a sign to Americans that we care about them.'' Mrs. Howell, who returned to Charlottesville from Washington on Saturday, last spoke with her husband around 5 a.m. Friday, noon in Kuwait, she said. That was Saddam's deadline for the American embassy to close. ``I didn't sleep all night the night before,'' Mrs. Howell said. Howell reassured her that the embassy was safe, she said. ``He was eating lunch,'' Mrs. Howell said. ``He was very calm.'' Mrs. Howell returned to the United States from Kuwait on July 27 to attend her father's 84th birthday celebration. She was aware of mounting tensions between Iraq and Kuwait, she said, but no one expected an invasion. ``When I left, there were 30,000 Iraqi troops sitting at the border, but we thought that was Saddam Hussein's way of extorting money from Kuwait, '' she said. Howell, 51, was scheduled to step down as ambassador this month and join his wife as he resumed duties in Washington. He has served as ambassador to Kuwait for three years and was in diplomatic positions in Algiers, Lebanon and Egypt. ``This is our third war,'' Mrs. Howell said. Howell worked for the U.S. Foreign Service in Cairo during the Six-Day War in 1967 and in Beirut when Lebanon's civil war broke out in 1975. Howell graduated from the University of Virginia in 1961 and received his doctorate in government and foreign affairs from the school in 1965. Mrs. Howell is a graduate of the university's nursing school. University of Virginia Professor R.K. Ramazani describes his former student as imaginative, systematic, hard-working and thorough. ``He's a very accomplished diplomat,'' said Ramazani, who served as a consultant to President Jimmy Carter during the American hostage crisis in Iran. The Howells plan on retiring in Charlottesville, where Howell hopes to teach at the university.

DOC.HEAD: Schools To Instruct 1 Million Students In Gas Mask Use
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: More than a million Israeli schoolchildren will get an intensive course in the use of gas masks and other ways of surviving chemical warfare to prepare for a possible Iraqi attack, officials said Sunday. The program, to begin when school starts Sept. 2, follows threats earlier this year by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to attack Israel with chemical weapons if an Israeli nuclear attack is aimed at Iraq. ``The children will be instructed how to put on their gas masks and walk up to the upper floors of the school, to previously sealed off classrooms,'' Ran Levine, deputy director general of the Education Ministry, told Israel radio. According to officials, the instruction will be given to all Israeli students, both Jews and Arabs, between age 5 and 18. Some 5,000 teachers will take a course on using the protective equipment. Two teachers from each school will then complete instruction for the students by Sept. 20. Each school will receive a videotape and 25 gas masks for demonstrations, officials said. Dr. Avigdor Klingman, the Education Ministry's coordinator for crisis intervention, said the course also is designed to quiet children's fears about gas masks. ``A child who thinks that he can't wear a mask because it is too scary, then puts it on with the help of his teacher, paints with it, or does exercises with it then sees that the devil is not so bad,'' Klingman said. Gas masks will not be handed out at schools, but will be distributed to families through neighborhood civil defense offices. Despite the recent crisis, Israeli authorities have decided not to distribute the masks to the public now for fear of causing panic or sending a wrong signal to Iraq. Saddam first warned he would use chemical weapons against Israel last April. During the current crisis, he has threatened to attack Israel in response to a U.S. military strike, but he has not specifically mentioned chemical weapons. Bomb drills have always been part of Israel's school curriculum. In the past four years, instruction on protection against chemical warfare has been introduced at some 250 middle and high schools. This year the program is being expanded to all schools.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Criticizes Iraq, Prays for Those `Unjustly Held'
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: In his first public condemnation of Iraq, Pope John Paul II on Sunday denounced Saddam Hussein's detention of foreigners, praying for those ``unjustly kept far from their homeland.'' In the first weeks following the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, the pontiff made no public statements about the crisis. On Wednesday, speaking to a small group of Japanese Buddhists, the pope alluded to the crisis for the first time, saying peace was being threatened. Although he did not mention any geographical area, the reference to the Persian Gulf was clear. On Sunday, the pope specifically cited the crisis, following his noontime prayer from the balcony of his summer palace in the hills outside Rome, where pilgrims were gathered for his blessing. ``On this day of the Lord, I feel the duty to invite you to pray for peace in the Persian Gulf, where recently, a truly worrisome situation has developed,'' the pope said. `We have been witnesses to grave violations of international rights and of the U.N. charter, as well as of ethical principles that must prevail among all peoples,'' he said. ``The mistrust of one side versus another is dramatically increasing and international order, constructed with so much effort and at the sacrifice of so many human lives, is gravely threatened,'' John Paul continued. The pontiff prayed for peace in the entire Middle East, asking God to ``enlighten those who control the fates of peoples so that they will find fair solutions for the existing problems and make the star of peace shine strongly on the tried peoples of the Persian Gulf as on all the peoples of the Middle East, above all those who suffer in Lebanon and in Palestine.'' The pontiff ended with a prayer to the Virgin Mary for the foreigners prevented from leaving Iraq and Kuwait. ``Mary, queen of peace, intercede for us and above all for those who suffer because they are unjustly kept far from their homeland. Lord, give us peace.'' Saddam has said foreigners caught in Iraq and Kuwait will be used as human shields to protect key Iraqi installations. About 21,000 of them are Westerners, including 3,000 Americans and 3,000 Britons.

DOC.HEAD: Rash of Robberies Target Expensive Status-Symbol Watches
DOC.TEXT: Rolex watches, gilded badges of wealth and luxury, have become an emblem of violence and death as robbers who covet the expensive timepieces are killing their owners for them, police say. Sam Sabbah was meeting his wife and a painter in his new Beverly Hills home last June when an intruder fatally shot him and took his Rolex. A few days later, west Los Angeles transmission shop owner Melvin Thompson broke with his usual routine and wore his Rolex to work, intending to take it to a jeweler. A robber hit at closing, taking the watch and cash and shooting Thompson to death. This month, nursery owner Donald McKinsey hung on to his $10,000 watch during a robbery and was shot to death by gunmen who had posed as customers. A Rolex watch can range in price from about $1,000 to more than $20,000. Some of the 18-karat gold timepieces are encrusted with diamonds. It's not the watch the robbers want, but rather the money it commands. The police division covering Los Angeles' affluent west side dealt with 49 Rolex robberies from September to July. Beverly Hills has been averaging one a month, according to police Lt. Robert Curtis. Police say no one individual or group is responsible. There have been arrests but watch robberies continue. Sometimes the victims were followed home from a shopping mall or other public place where an expensive watch on a wrist could be spotted, police say. In the McKinsey murder, however, the killers came to the nursery and discussed renting plants, then returned the next day to do the robbery. Nursery office manager Ken Steller said later that McKinsey knew of the watch robberies but continued to wear the timepiece. ``It was his signature,'' Steller said. Car salesman Bob Gordon of Santa Monica thinks similarly of his $17,750 Rolex. ``I love that watch. It's a sign of my success,'' he said. ``But I don't think I can wear it, certainly not to work. It's too dangerous.'' Gordon immediately handed the watch over to three robbers who entered his office Aug. 16. A gun was pointed at his heart but the trio left him unharmed. A police pursuit ended with three arrests and the watch was recovered. Last week, the district attorney's office charged Eric Jones, 23, his brother Derrick Jones, 20, and Isaac Williams 21, with the Gordon robbery. Williams was also charged with a similar robbery that occurred the day before in Beverly Hills. A Rolex watch and $140,000 in jewelry were taken. Those were only the latest arrests. Los Angeles County sheriff's detectives and South Bay police seized two men in May in a probe of watch robberies in which victims were often approached in parking structures. A Rolex robbery in December led to the arrest of two other men in Redondo Beach. The investigation encompassed similar holdups in affluent Rolling Hills Estates and Palos Verdes Estates. It's not clear in every case the robber knew he was getting a Rolex. Los Angeles police Detective Dan Andrews notes there are other kinds of valuable watches, and that ``it's the money behind the watch that's the target.'' Andrews investigated the McKinsey murder as well as the killing a year ago of restaurateur Andre Coffyn at a westside bistro. Coffyn was chatting with customers on a patio when a gunman barged in and demanded: ``Give me your watches.'' Coffyn handed over a gold Omega watch and wallet. The bandit shot him to death and fled.

DOC.HEAD: Graduation Prayer: No Harm, Says Governor; ACLU Disagrees
DOC.TEXT: To Gov. Norm Bangerter, an impending legal battle over the saying of prayers at public school graduations is a local issue that scarcely affects predominantly Mormon Utah's image in the global marketplace. Nor does he see the bitterly divisive issue tainting Salt Lake City's bid to be host of the 1998 Winter Olympics. ``I doubt anyone who's going to come to the Olympics worries whether there's prayer in graduation at high school. I doubt that it's going to cross many people's minds,'' Bangerter said in an interview. But Michele Parish-Pixler, state director of the American Civil Liberties Union, is among many non-Mormons who believe the governor's attitude helps perpetuate the outsider's image of Utah as a narrow-minded theocracy. ``We spend all this money to promote tourism, then we do this stuff,'' she said. Perhaps not since non-Mormon efforts to permit hard liquor to be served by the drink failed in 1968 has an issue so sharply divided Utah residents along religious lines. The battle was joined July 30 when the ACLU filed suit in federal court seeking to ban prayer from public school graduations.
