Bangerter, a Mormon and a Republican, said he may ask the state Legislature for a special appropriation to help the two school districts named in the suit defend themselves in court. ``I felt local districts were being somewhat intimidated by the threat of a lawsuit in doing what they desired to do,'' he said. The U.S. Supreme Court banned organized, school-sponsored prayer sessions for students in 1962. Bangerter believes a legal gray area remains for opening and closing prayers at events such as commencement. Seventy percent of Utah's 1.7 million residents are members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints and most of the graduation prayers are delivered by Mormons. Many defend the practice, saying critics are taking potshots at a faith defenders say is virtually synonymous with a healthy and industrious lifestyle. Others decry the church's influence on daily life in Utah, saying Mormons have no conception of the ostracism felt by everyone else. ``It's not just prayers at high school graduation,'' Parish-Pixler said. ``The governor brings this down to kids sitting through a 30-second prayer once in 12 years. The people who go to school here deal with it at every activity. ``This is a state that's reluctant to give up its church-state status. That does not play well with people on the outside. They come, stay a couple of years, and leave. ``They say, `My kids were so unhappy we had to leave.' Every time Utah loses somebody that way, the message goes out to corporate America that this is a hardship post.'' To be sure, Utah isn't the only state to confront the issue. Last month, the 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals affirmed a Rhode Island Court's ban on graduation prayers. Iowa courts have done the same. In California, the state Supreme Court has been asked to review contrary rulings on whether the practice violates the First Amendment, Parish-Pixler said. State Sen. Frances Farley, a non-Mormon Democrat who moved to Utah two decades ago, is saddened by the dispute. During a recent bipartisan Senate caucus in which the subject was discussed, she said Utah ``should grow up.'' And in what she now considers an intemperate remark, she added, ``To be crass, it's not good for business.'' ``What I said on the floor of the Senate was more or less a plea of understanding for people who move to Utah, and love it, and make it their home, but are not accustomed to the pervasiveness of what seems like the dominant religion,'' she said. The Mormon Church has remained silent on the lawsuit. But Elder Dallin H. Oaks, a member of the church's Council of the Twelve Apostles and a former Utah Supreme Court justice, defended graduation prayers in a May column in The Wall Street Journal.

DOC.HEAD: Rescuers Use Iced Tea to Douse Car Fire, Save Woman
DOC.TEXT: A woman whose car crashed and burst into flames was rescued by a quick-thinking couple who used a jug of iced tea to douse the flames. ``Thank God for my wife's iced tea,'' said Michael Rodrigue, a Sarasota, Fla., firefighter and paramedic who pulled Natalie A. Corcoran, 60, from her burning car Saturday. Police said Corcoran was driving north on Interstate 95 at about 7 p.m. when her car slammed into a highway sign, flipped over and skidded along the road, bursting into flames. Rodrigue and his wife, Kim, a registered nurse, pulled over to help her, grabbing a plastic jug of iced tea from their car. ``I could hear her screaming, `Help me! Help me! I'm burning!''' Rodrigue said. He got down on his knees and began pouring poured iced tea on the flames while he tried to free Corcoran, who was wearing a seat belt, from the car. ``Her right shoe was burning and her legs were almost on fire,'' he said. A second motorist, Judy Volner, called 911 on her car telephone and had a small knife to cut the seat belt to free Corcoran. And a truck driver, Armand Brodeur, stopped and brought out a small fire extinguisher to help. Rodrigue finally managed to pull got Corcoran from out the car and away from the wreckage as fire and rescue trucks arrived. Corcoran was taken by ambulance to Yale-New Haven Hospital where she was reported in stable condition.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Linda Ronstadt blames arena concerts and radio programmers for the ``awful'' state of pop music. ``What really ruined pop music is the architecture that it's presented in,'' Ms. Ronstadt told The Pittsburgh Press in Sunday's editions. ``Any place that's bigger than 11,000 is just not a suitable environment for music.'' Describing the sound in such places as ``swimmy and boomy,'' she said, ``I hate playing in them, and I will never be in an audience at one of them.'' Of the current music scene, the singer-songwriter said, ``It's awful.'' One reason: ``the corporate approach to radio programming.'' ``If you're a musician and you come from Memphis or Nashville or New Orleans, areas that have some of the richest musical heritage in the country, you have to go to Los Angeles in order to do it,'' Ms. Ronstadt said. Twenty-five years ago, regional sounds like Memphis rhythm-and-blues and Motown found national niches, according to Ms. Ronstadt. Ms. Ronstadt's next pop album probably will include some New Orleans tunes by Allan Toussaint or Irma Thomas, she said. Her most recent album is ``Cry Like a Rainstorm, Howl Like the Wind.''

Pop singer-songwriter Sinead O'Connor has sung her last note at the Garden State Arts Center. Ms. O'Connor, known for the hit single ``Nothing Compares 2 U'' and her extremely short haircut, threatened Friday to walk out on a 9,000-member audience if the American national anthem was played at her concert. Ms. O'Connor is Irish. Backstage staff relented out of fear that a last-minute cancellation would cause a commotion, said Dennis Ingoglia, a spokesman for the New Jersey Highway Authority, which operates the center. She gave no reason for the request, Ingoglia said in Saturday's editions of The Star-Ledger of Newark. But George Zilocchi, the authority's acting executive director, gave his reasons for banning Ms. O'Connor from appearing at the concert hall. ``No performer who does not agree to have the national anthem played will be allowed to perform,'' Zilocchi said. Efforts to reach Ms. O'Connor's spokeswoman, Elaine Schock of Pelham, N.Y., were not immediately successful Sunday. There was no telephone listing under Ms. Schock's name there.

Former Olympic women's marathon champion Joan Benoit Samuelson is supporting a campaign aimed at keeping guns locked away from kids. ``Having young children around the house, I see them getting into everything,'' said Samuelson. ``It drives it home that guns need to be stored properly and beyond the reach of kids.'' A proposed referendum would ask whether adults should be held responsible if children under 16 gain unsupervised access to firearms. Such a law would require that guns be stored in locked boxes or protected by trigger locks. Maximum penalties would be $1,000 in fines and a year in jail. Portland Police Chief Michael Chitwood began the campaign after the Maine Legislature rejected a bill to keep guns out of the hands of children. He cited the fatal shootings of eight children within a year and a half. The gun-safety campaign is seeking 50,000 signatures on petitions to put the question on the November 1991 ballot. So far, about 10,000 signatures have been collected, said Chitwood. The Sportsman's Alliance of Maine is opposing the measure and says that gun-safety programs are more effective than laws in protecting people.

DOC.TEXT: Veteran soap actress Frances Reid says times have changed for aspiring actors and actresses. ``In my day, you could have a career if you stood up straight and spoke your lines loud and clear,'' the Emmy nominee said in the Sept. 1 issue of TV Guide. ``Now, being prepared is more important than ever. To survive today's competition, you have to be able to act, sing, dance ... and strip.'' Reid, who once landed a stage role as Roxanne opposite Jose Ferrer's Cyrano de Bergerac, today plays great-great-grandmother Alice Horton on NBC's ``Days of Our Lives.'' She also helps with career-orientation sessions for the television performers' union, the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists. ``A lot of Hollywood hopefuls still think you can get discovered in a pink angora sweater at Schwab's drug store,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Nebraska Senator Says No Loss Of Life For Cheap Oil
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS pvs lede to CORRECT American's to Americans
DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Declaring that young Americans shouldn't die in battle just to keep gasoline prices low, Sen. Bob Kerry on Sunday said the U.S. should abandon the notion of cheap oil. The Nebraska Democrat, a Vietnam veteran and Congressional Medal Of Honor recipient, said he supported President Bush's decision to send troops to the Persian Gulf, but only as a means of preventing an Iraqi invasion of Saudi Arabia. ``I question the response that says that we're going to go there and have our young people die so that we can have cheap oil here at home,'' Kerry said in an appearance on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press.'' ``The only justification that I find that is legitimate is that ... we're the only nation that could move quick enough to prevent an invasion of Saudi Arabia.'' Congressional Democrats have generally supported Bush during the Middle East crisis, although there has been some grumbling that the president should clarify his long-term objectives in the Persian Gulf region. American troops were sent to the area after Iraqi forces easily conquered Kuwait in an Aug. 2 invasion. Iraq annexed the oil-rich emirate six days later. Congressional leaders have asked for a White House briefing next Tuesday on the Middle East developments. Like most members of Congress, which has been recessed in August, Kerry has been in his home while the tense situation in the Persian Gulf has unfolded. He expressed some frustration that Bush had not provided lawmakers with more details about the administration's intentions in the gulf region. ``We aren't, it seems to me, being provided a sufficient amount of information to really engage meaningfully in a debate about whether or not this (U.S. deployment of military forces) is appropriate,'' said Kerry, who is not among the congressional leadership and knew nothing of Tuesday's planned briefing. ``I know from reading the newspapers that it's hot in the desert and the chow is bad,'' he added. Kerry suggested that American demand for cheap oil contributed to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's rise to power in the Middle East. ``We in general have been blinded by money ... and as a consequence we put into place policy that encouraged Hussein to become extremely strong,'' he said. Kerry said Americans are being ``very tolerant of higher oil prices' that have resulted from the gulf tensions, ``even though they are grumbling a bit about it.''

DOC.HEAD: 20 Dead In Capsizing Of Crowded Tourist Boat
DOC.TEXT: Rescuers on Sunday pulled more bodies from a lake where an overloaded tourist boat overturned during a moon-gazing cruise a night earlier. At least 21 people drowned and 34 were missing and feared dead, police said. Shell Taiwan Ltd., which chartered the boat for a weekend tour, said in a statement that 88 people were on board, including three British executives and 82 other company staffers and family members. About 200 rescuers, including divers, searched the picturesque Sun Moon Lake in one of Taiwan's most popular tourist districts for survivors through Saturday night and Sunday, police said. No Americans were known to be aboard. ``We are extremely distressed by this great tragedy,'' said Jonathan D. Crossman, a survivor of the accident and president of Shell Taiwan Ltd., a subsidiary of the British company. Crossman and his 7-year-old daughter, Nicola, was rescued by boats that rushed to the scene but his wife, Julia, 40, and a son, Robert, 6, were missing, Shell official Tseng Tung-shin said. Rescuers said a baby was among a handful of people rescued from a cabin with windows that were fixed shut and could not be opened. But Crossman said 10 bodies, including three or four children, were recovered from the closed cabin. Sobbing relatives of the Taiwanese victims and many of the survivors burned paper money in a traditional offering to the dead at a tent set up near the dock, where investigators were examining the recovered bodies. Crossman said the vessel was chartered by the oil company for a weekend cruise for employees on the lake in Nantou, 165 miles southwest of the capital Taipei. He said the boat suddenly overturned as it was making a left turn about 50 yards from shore and he was tossed overboard from an upper deck. Newspapers quoted survivors as saying strong winds overturned the boat. Police arrested boat owner Hsu Ching-hsin on suspicion of unintentional manslaughter. They said the boat lacked a commercial license to operate on the lake and carried more than its 60-person capacity when the accident occurred at 9:30 p.m. Saturday, the eve of the Chinese Valentine Day festival in which moon-gazing is a traditional part of the celebrations.
