DOC.HEAD: Epileptic Charged In Accident That Killed Boy
DOC.TEXT: A man whose driver's license was taken away because he has epilepsy was charged with homicide after he suffered a seizure while driving and struck and killed a 7-year-old boy, authorities said. James Cheatham, 23, of Hazelwood was ordered Friday to stand trial in the Aug. 3 death of Ryan Maszle in West Mifflin. At a hearing Friday, the arresting officer, Joseph Sotak, said he initially suspected Cheatham was under the influence of drugs or alcohol because Cheatham said nothing after the accident and could barely walk. ``I had to practically carry him over to my police car,'' he said. About 15 minutes after the accident, however, Cheatham recovered from his seizure. After the hearing in Allegheny County Court, Cheatham was charged with involuntary manslaughter and homicide by vehicle. Cheatham's attorney argued that because his client was suffering a seizure at the time, he could not have formed the intent to harm and therefore the charges were unfounded. Ryan was sitting on a fence with his sister and cousin when the car struck him. ``The car came speeding down the road. I happened to look up the road and said, `My God!' and the next thing I knew, the kids flew,'' said his grandmother, Ada Sarvor. ``I watched until the car hit the fence. It happened so fast.'' Cheatham also was charged with aggravated assault, reckless endangerment, driving under suspension, reckless driving and carrying a firearm without a license. Cheatham lost his driver's license last year because of his condition.

DOC.HEAD: Waldheim Praised at Home, Rebuffed Abroad for Iraq Mission
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Austrian President Kurt Waldheim, who has spent much of the past four years in the shadow of his World War II record, won warm praise here Sunday for his mission to Iraq that freed about 100 countrymen. But he was reprimanded outside Austria for breaking the isolation the Western world imposed on Iraq after it invaded and annexed Kuwait. Waldheim, in an interview Sunday, insisted he did not break with the West's solidarity against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. Waldheim returned home early Sunday with the Austrians, who were among the thousands of foreigners stranded in Iraq because of the Persian Gulf crisis. He was the first Western leader to meet with Saddam since the Iraqi president sent his army into Kuwait on Aug. 2. ``Waldheim took his greatest risk of this job and probably of his entire career, and he won,'' said the mass daily Kurier. He and the Austrian hostages were greeted at the airport by family and well-wishers, some of whom held signs saying, ``Bravo Waldheim.'' Waldheim, a former U.N. secretary-general, has spent the four years of his presidency as a pariah in world politics and an embarrassment to many of his countrymen because of his wartime record. He is barred from entering the United States because of charges that he knew about or participated in war crimes as a German army intelligence officer in the Balkans during the war. Waldheim has acknowledged concealing his past, but denies any wrongdoing. His term in the largely ceremonial Austrian presidency runs until 1992, and he has not indicated yet whether he intends to run again. Austrian Chancellor Franz Vranitzky, who reportedly was skeptical when the visit was announced last Thursday, told the national radio that ``the most important point is that we are enthusiastic of having all our Austrians out of the region.'' Outside Austria, however, officials and the media were less admiring. ``I think one can sympathize with the leader of a country wanting to get his own citizens out,'' U.S. national security adviser Brent Scowcroft said on ABC-TV's ``This Week With David Brinkley.'' However, he added, ``It would have been much more helpful if he had pleaded for the tens or hundreds of thousands of foreigners who find themselves trapped inside Kuwait and Iraq.'' Asked if he wished Waldheim had not gone to Iraq, Scowcroft responded, ``I think he could have done more.'' Italian Foreign Minister Gianni De Michelis, speaking to reporters in Venice, expressed his ``reserve and perplexity'' about the visit. Italy's La Stampa, which comes out in Turin, carried an article headlined ``A gift to Waldheim: 76 hostages,'' and subheaded ``His visit breaks Iraqi isolation.'' Waldheim, in a Sunday interview with British Broadcasting Corp. said he realized before his trip that some people would criticize his effort, but ``I do not consider that justified. ``I made crystal clear that we stick to Western solidarity, that we implement all the resolutions which the Security Council has adopted and that this, my humanitarian mission, does not in any way mean that we are trying to break out of that Western solidarity,'' Waldheim said.

DOC.HEAD: `Open' Saudi Coverage Leads to Disbanded Press Pool
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon disbanded its Persian Gulf news media pool Sunday, saying it is not needed because open coverage is now being permitted. ``The decision by the government of Saudi Arabia to allow reporters from the U.S. and other countries to cover the military operation in the Gulf region makes it unnecessary to continue the National Media Pool,'' the Defense Department said. The 17-member pool left Washington Aug. 12 and has been filing press and broadcast reports and transmitting still photographs daily since its arrival in Saudi Arabia Aug. 13.

DOC.HEAD: University Initiates Scholarships for Eastern Europeans
DOC.TEXT: A small liberal arts college is giving two Eastern Europeans a taste of U.S. capitalism and competition under its Scholars for Freedom program. ``We hope to show them the ways of a market economy and instruct them in the ways of a democratic and open system,'' said Gilbert Ghez, a Roosevelt University business professor who runs the program. Peter Leidl, 21, of Czechoslovakia will take undergraduate business courses at the university, and Laszlo Pribusz, 24, of Hungary will study graduate computer science, Ghez said. Many U.S. universities say they can't offer specific financial aid to Eastern Europeans, who are taking advantage of freedoms recently won in their own countries by seeking to study in the United States. But Roosevelt _ working with Scandinavian Airlines, multinational corporations and private groups _ is offering two students $20,000 in full tuition, room and board for the 1990-91 school year as well as round-trip air fare. Competition for the scholarships was keen. About 500 people applied before the list was weeded down to 50 students, who were interviewed by professors at Roosevelt, a school with about 6,000 students. The two students chosen are scheduled to arrive at O'Hare International Airport on Tuesday. They will study problems faced by Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Poland and Romania alike: turning from planned to market economies and dealing with rampant shortages and inflation. The Scholars for Freedom program hopes to train students in capitalism and return them home to use those skills, Mark Holtzblatt, a Roosevelt professor of science and international business. While the university so far has been able to offer students just one free year of study, Ghez said even that experience should prove valuable to Eastern governments. ``I'm not saying they'll be CEOs right away, but they will be able to take the skills they've learned here in America and use them over there,'' he said. The university hopes to offer scholarships to as many as 20 people for the program's second year, he added.

DOC.HEAD: Keenan Didn't Want Freedom Without Fellow Hostage, Doctor Says
DOC.TEXT: Freed Irish hostage Brian Keenan didn't want to be released unless fellow prisoner John McCarthy was also set free by their Lebanese captors, one of Keenan's doctors said Sunday. ``He said `no,' he would not go without John McCarthy,'' Dr. Sean Blake said a day after Keenan arrived in Dublin. ``But in the end, he had no option. They just told him, `we want you out.' '' Blake is one of the doctors tending Keenan at Mater hospital in Dublin, where he was taken for a checkup after his flight home from Syria aboard a government jet. Keenan was freed Friday and turned over to Irish officials in Syria a day later. Keenan, a 39-year-old Belfast teacher, spent his first full day back in Ireland making phone calls from the hospital to the families of McCarthy and other hostages he left behind in Lebanon. Keenan said Saturday that he saw American hostages Terry Anderson and Thomas Sutherland during his captivity, and that they were in good spirits. He also said he saw McCarthy, with whom he spent much of his four years and four months in captivity, on Thursday and that the 33-year-old British journalist was well. American former hostage Frank Reed, who spent about three years in the same room or house as Keenan and McCarthy, greeted the Irish teacher at Dublin airport Saturday night. Reed was released April 30, eight days after fellow U.S. hostage Robert Polhill was freed. Two Swiss Red Cross workers, Emanuel Christen and Elio Erriquez, were freed earlier this month. Six Americans, four Britons, two West Germans and an Italian are still believed held by extremist Moslems in Lebanon. Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, was kidnapped March 16, 1985 and is the longest-held. Blake, a cardiologist, said Keenan was somewhat malnourished and unfit from lack of physical activity. But otherwise, he appeared ``very well.'' Sister Gemma Byrne, the hospital's chief executive, said Keenan had lost 42 pounds in captivity and ``must have a complete rest.'' ``His first reaction on going into his room was it was the first bed he had seen in 4{ years,'' she said. Dr. Richard Firth, an endocrinologist who examined Keenan, said his general condition was ``excellent'' though test results were not in.

DOC.HEAD: Demonstrators Reoccupy Central Square After Clash
DOC.TEXT: About 300 anti-government demonstrators occupied a central square in the capital for a fifth day Sunday, a day after 48 people were arrested and two reportedly hurt in a clash with police. The latest arrests brought to 80 the number of people detained in and around the square in the last week, police said Sunday in a communique. On Saturday night, a clash erupted after police moved in, armed with clubs and shields. At least two people were reported hospitalized. The police communique called on the public to support the authorities and ``disassociate themselves from the destabilizing demonstrations of ill-intentioned elements, which can create dangerous tensions.'' On Sunday, demonstrators at the square shouted slogans demanding the resignation of President Ion Iliescu. Critics accuse Iliescu and his associates, who won free elections earlier this year, of keeping many of the policies of the authoritarian Communist leader Nicolae Ceausescu. Ceausescu and his wife Elena were ousted and executed in December's popular uprising. The demonstrators at University Square, located at the main intersection on the capital's fashionable Balcescu Boulevard, disrupted traffic and forced motorists to use side streets. Saturday evening's violence broke out when about 2,000 riot police, military police and firefighters arrived to clear the area. They were greeted by showers of rocks, bottles and firebombs from the hundreds of angry demonstrators. The confrontations spread to nearby streets, where windows were broken and several fires broke out. The square was the site of a 53-day anti-government demonstration and traffic blockade earlier this summer organized by students and activists. This week's rallies appeared to be motivated by the deteriorating economy and food and energy shortages. It attracted mostly lower-income workers.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Keeps Up Pressure On Embassies In Kuwait
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with State Department saying two more U.S. citizens detained in Kuwait. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Defiant diplomats in Kuwait held out for a second day Sunday, with some embassies guarded by Iraqi troops and lacking electricity, water and telephone service. There were no reports that the Iraqis, who had ordered all embassies closed by Friday, were using force against the diplomats. However, the United States, Britain and France all reported Sunday that more of their citizens in Kuwait had been rounded up. One of the reasons the embassies defied the Iraqi order to close down was that they wanted to try to help their citizens trapped in the occupied emirate. According to reports reaching foreign ministries in Europe and elsewhere, the Iraqis cut off electricity and other utilities Saturday at some missions, including the U.S. Embassy, after the diplomats refused to shut down. Iraq, which invaded Kuwait Aug. 2 and annexed it six days later, says Kuwait is now part of Iraq and thus needs no embassies. Reports Sunday said the U.S., British, French, Hungarian and Danish embassies were among those surrounded by troops. In other developments: _ The British Foreign Office said contact was still possible with the four diplomats holed up in the British mission. Some other governments said diplomats at their embassies were free to come and go. _ West Germany's Foreign Ministry said its embassy's water and electricity were cut off Sunday. The ministry said it still has contact with the embassy, and West German diplomats were working to set up radio communication for the French embassy, which has lost contact with Paris. _ The French Embassy in Kuwait is without water and electricity and telephone communication has been severed, West German officials said. The East German Embassy also was without water and electricity. _ Water and power to Canada's embassy has also been cut, Canada's External Affairs department said Sunday, and troops who had surrounded the embassy Friday moved about 100 yards away. The department said the mission was making regular telephone contact with Canadians stranded in Kuwait. _ The Japanese Foreign Ministry said Sunday several soldiers were patrolling near its embassy, and water and electricity remained cut off. _ Denmark said electricity at its embassy was cut Sunday and shortwave radio contact had been lost. Only the Danish ambassador remains at the embassy, which has been surrounded by Iraqi troops. The United States, the 12 European Community states and many other countries have refused to close their Kuwait embassies, saying the closing order violated international law. They say going along with the Iraqi order to close could be construed as recognition of the annexation. Meanwhile, the State Department said Sunday it had been informed that two additional Americans have been taken into custody by Iraqi troops. Department spokeswoman Anita Stockman said the information was relayed to the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait by telephone. Although officials had no way of confirming the information, she said embassy personnel had reason to believe it was accurate. She had no additional details about those arrested. Britain's Foreign Office said Sunday that Iraqi troops rounded up eight more Britons in Kuwait City. It said the eight adults, seized Saturday, were being held at a civilian establishment in Kuwait City, bringing to 147 the number of Britons rounded up since the invasion. And France's Foreign Ministry said Iraqi troops have forced eight more French, including two women and two children, from their homes in Kuwait. They were taken to a hotel where other French citizens rounded up earlier were staying, the ministry said. About 60 of the approximately 270 French citiziens who were in Kuwait at the time of Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion have been detained.

DOC.HEAD: Goverment Gains Ground in Advance Toward Strategic Fort
With AM-Barefoot Guerrillas, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The government said Sunday its troops overran a rebel-held island and killed more than 80 Tamil guerrillas in an advance toward a strategic northeast fort under siege by the insurgents. Military officials in Colombo say government troops are now within about two miles of the 17th-century Jaffna Fort, where about 250 policemen and soldiers have been trapped for 10 weeks. Vowing to crush the Tamil Tiger rebels once and for all, the government has staked its prestige on breaking the siege of the fort, the Sinhalese-controlled government's only outpost in Tamil-dominated Jaffna town 185 miles northeast of Colombo. There was no confirmation of the government claim that its forces captured Mandativu Island after a fierce three-hour battle Saturday night. Conventional communications to the Jaffna Peninsula were cut after June 11, when the Tigers broke a 13-month-old cease-fire with the government. The combatants use radios to communicate with colleagues outside the peninsula. The last word from the Tigers was Friday when a guerrilla spokesman in Geneva acknowledged government forces were trying to advance from Kayts Island to Mandativu Island. Government troops landed on Kayts Island on Wednesday, disloging Tamil fighters. The islands are connected by a causeway that continues across the Jaffna lagoon and ends just beside Jaffna Fort. But the causeway is heavily mined, the military officials said. In the seven years since militants from the Tamil minority revolted against Sinhalese rule, the Tigers have proved devastatingly effective at making and planting mines. Military officials in Colombo, who under briefing rules cannot be identified, claimed 84 Tigers and only two government soldiers were killed in the battle for Mandativu Island. They said advancing troops found the bodies of 28 rebels on Mandativu and killed 16 others who tried to swim to safety. Another 40 Tigers were killed in strafing from a helicopter gunship as they tried to reach the mainland, the officials said. The government says it now expects to reach Jaffna Fort by Monday. Since launching its latest offensive against the Tigers, the government says it has stepped up aerial attacks on rebel positions around the star-shaped fort, a legacy of Portuguese, Dutch and British colonial rule on this island off the southern tip of India. The Tigers have not acknowledged any losses but have accused the government of killing more than 300 Tamil civilians in bombing and strafing raids and ground fire on the Jaffna Peninsula, where 850,000 people live. The government says 5,000 people have been killed since June 11, when the Tigers broke the cease-fire in northern and eastern Sri Lanka where most Tamils live. That brings to at least 14,000 the total number of victims of the 7-year-old Tamil insurrection. Tamils make up 18 percent of the Indian Ocean island's 16 million people. They have long complained that the Sinhalese majority discriminates against them in the jobs, education and use of the Sinhala language. Militants sought to create a separate homeland for Tamils in the northeast. Sinhalese, who account for 75 percent of the Sri Lankan population, have dominated politics and the military since this country gained independence from Britain in 1949.

DOC.HEAD: Europe Reportedly Becoming Drug Mafia's Main Cocaine Market
DOC.TEXT: Colombian drug cartels and the Mafia are building a cocaine empire in Western European countries, which have replaced the United States as the biggest market for the drug, a Bogota newspaper reported Sunday. ``Consumption in Spain, Holland and Italy is leaving the North American market behind,'' said Bogota's El Tiempo newspaper, citing a joint report by the international police organization Interpol and the Colombian intelligence police, known as the DAS. The Bogota offices of both Interpol and the DAS were closed Sunday, and no one could be reached for comment. The European market will continue to grow because of the Italian Mafia's intention to preserve its distribution monopoly and the Colombian cartel's desire to capture part of the market, according to the study. It said the cartel and the Mafia are likely to form agreements to flood the market with cocaine. El Tiempo quoted the report as saying the dramatic growth of the cocaine market in Western Europe is fueled by high prices. The drug is sold in Europe for between $27,500 and $115,000 a kilogram, compared to between $10,000 and $20,000 in the United States, according to the document. A kilogram is 2.2 pounds. Profits from the European business are enormous, the report added, because distributors receive cocaine that is 90 to 94 percent pure and sell a product that is only 45 percent pure. The report cited Spain as the principal receiver of cocaine from Latin America and the main trafficking center for drug destined for the European markets. The report also said cocaine laboratories have been discovered in Spain as well as in France and Italy. Cocaine processing has traditionally been confined to Colombia, but the country's war against the cartels and its crackdown on imports of processing chemicals have reportedly forced drug bosses to move some of their operations elsewhere. ``Although for some the detection of these (European) processing centers has not been alarming, the facilities certainly are providing a supply of hundreds of kilograms,'' the report said. The enormous expansion of the cocaine business, combined with the participation of other criminal organizations, has reduced the importance of the Colombian drug barons, especially the Medellin cartel. ``The Medellin cartel has begun to lose part of its key members and along with them part of the power they exercised over world distribution networks,'' said the police report. It estimated that the cartel's share of the world cocaine market has been reduced from 75 percent to 40 percent. In the past eight months, several key cartel figures have been killed in shootouts with Colombian authorities. The organization's leader, Pablo Escobar, the target of a manhunt by police, is in hiding and reportedly unable to run the cartel's day-to-day operations.

DOC.HEAD: Legislative Committee Agenda Includes Proposed Press Law
DOC.TEXT: China is preparing to enact a law to prevent ``the abuse of press freedom'' and ensure that the media support the Communist Party, Hong Kong newspapers reported Sunday. The standing committee of China's legislature, the National People's Congress, was to meet starting Tuesday, said two pro-Beijing papers and one independent daily. Zhang Husheng, spokesman for the standing committee, was quoted as saying no major personnel changes in the leadership were expected during the 10-day meeting in Beijing. The reports said Premier Li Peng would address the standing committee on ``recent international events,'' possibly the current crisis in the Middle East. China has generally supported the West during the crisis. Beijing says it opposes the use of military force to enforce the blockade on Iraq although it endorsed a U.N. Security Council resolution allowing such force to be used. Other reports will concern China's fragile economy and the status of scientific research in the country, the pro-Beijing papers, Ta Kung Pao and Wen Wei Po, and the independent Ming Pao said. The newspapers said the standing committee, which controls the rubber-stamp legislature, will also debate drafts of laws on copyrights, railroads, the signing of treaties and the export of labor. Spokesman Zhang was quoted by the papers as saying a press law, a publishing law and a maritime commerce law would be enacted soon. China's legislature has been debating a press law since 1984 and its contents have changed with the political winds. Papers quoted Wang Qianghua, who heads a team drafting the law, as saying the current version mandates that the press uphold the leadership of the Communist Party, Marxist thought and socialism. ``The law also protects against the abuse of press freedom,'' he said. Beijing Mayor Chen Xitong will also report on the status of the Asian Games, set to begin in September. Lack of money, the crisis in the Middle East and apparent mismanagement have hurt China's preparations for the games. Many analysts say the games are important to China's attempts to restore its international image following the bloody June 1989 crackdown on the pro-democracy movement. There is speculation in Hong Kong that more changes in China's government and Communist Party will come starting within the next few months and extending into the first half of next year. Since the June crackdown, China has undergone a large-scale military and political shake-up as conservative and relatively reform-minded groups compete for power. So far, 11 provinces have lost top officials, such as provincial party secretaries or provincial chiefs. Six out of the seven military regions have new commanders.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Claims 5 Million Join People's Militia
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi officials claim 5 million people have volunteered for a militia known as the Popular Army to back up the army in any Persian Gulf showdown, according to reports from Baghdad on Sunday. Every residential neighborhood in Baghdad now has a recruiting center for what is billed there as the Arabs' war against ``foreign invaders.'' The move was seen as part of an effort by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to mobilize Iraq's 17 million people following his Aug. 2 invasion of oil-rich Kuwait. It is unlikely that any of the volunteers will be used to fight the Americans and other countries deploying forces in neighboring Saudi Arabia. But they could help free regular troops in Iraq's 1 million-member armed forces to man front-line positions. Iraq's state-run television has shown film of troops handing out automatic weapons to men in civilian clothes in Baghdad's streets in recent days. Young men and women line up in the scorching summer heat for hours to enlist in the Popular Army, sources in the Iraqi capital reported. They spoke on condition of anonymity. ``We now have 5 million people under arms in the Popular Army,'' Information Minister Latif Nassayif Jassim told reporters in Baghdad on Sunday. One Baghdad volunteer said within days, those who sign up are sent to training centers, most of them outside the city, where they receive basic training on light weapons and are handed AK-47 automatic rifles. Those with good credentials, usually members or loyal supporters of the ruling Baath Party, are also given pistols or assigned to light Soviet-designed anti-aircraft guns.

DOC.HEAD: Slovak Rally Ends on Separatist Note
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Slovaks honored their former leader Sunday in a rally that ended with a strong call for independence. The two-day memorial to Andrej Hlinka included a seminar on his life, a Mass and the political rally with about 20 speakers. Hlinka was the leader of the Slovak National Party, the strongest political force in Slovakia. He opposed the Czechoslovak national government and after his death in 1938, his party collaborated with Hitler within the Slovak puppet state. He was accused of both separatism and fascism and his name was taboo in official history books under Communist rule. The newly found freedom that came with Czechoslovakia's peaceful revolution last year is seen by many Slovaks not only as an opportunity to reassess the country's history, but also a good time to demand full independence. Slovakia, the country's eastern part, contains roughly one-third of Czechoslovakia's 15.5 million people. Partly in answer to Slovaks' reawakening ethnic feelings, Czechoslovakia officially was renamed the Czech and Slovak Federative Republic on April 20. Before independent Czechoslovakia was founded by President Tomas Garrigue Masaryk in 1918, Slovakia was dominated by Hungarians for centuries. The Czech lands lived under strong German influence within the Austro-Hungarian empire. ``Hlinka once said the 1,200-year-long marriage with the Hungarians failed, and I say the 72-year old marriage with the Czechs failed as well,'' Vitezoslav Moric, leader of the Slovak National Party told the crowd of several thousand people Sunday. The Slovak National Party won 16 seats in the country's 300-seat Parliament in June elections, making it the fourth-strongest in Slovakia. But its popularity has been rising since. Jan Carnogursky, leader of the Christian Democratic Movement, the second-strongest political force in Slovakia, called for keeping Czechoslovakia together. He was booed off the stage. Participants in the rally adopted a demand that the Slovak Parliament and government ``take necessary measures to make Slovakia a sovereign state.'' It also called for making the Slovak language the only official language. Now, both the Czech and Slovak language are official throughout the country. The memorandum also called for a constitutional amendment giving Slovakia the right to secede.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Confers Via Telephone With Mubarak And Thatcher
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Top three grafs new with calls to Mubarak and Thatcher; pickup 2nd prv, ``The president xxx
DOC.TEXT: President Bush telephoned Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak and British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher on Sunday to discuss the Persian Gulf situation, White House aides said. They did not release any information as to the substance of the conversations. In addition to the telephone consultations with foreign leaders and briefings from aides on developments in the Middle East, Bush spent a sun-drenched Sunday with family members, attending church services and playing tennis and golf. The president, in the third week of a vacation at his seaside family home, received a briefing from his national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, early in the morning before heading off to church. He attended an annual breakfast for the vestrymen of St. Ann's Episcopal Church. Bush is an elder in the church and when he is in town he generally attends St. Ann's, which is just up the road from his home on Walker's Point. Bush was joined by his wife, Barbara; mother, Dorothy Walker Bush; son, Jeb; and assorted grandchildren for services at St. Ann's later in the morning. Bush waved off reporters' attempts to question him about developments in the Persian Gulf. He returned to Walker's Point for some tennis before an afternoon golf game. Bush left the policy comments to Scowcroft, who gave an ABC-TV interview and also took questions from a handful of reporters. Scowcroft said the Bush administration is comfortable with its policy on Iraq, as thousands of U.S. troops dig in to face Iraqi President Saddam Hussein on land and sea if necessary. He said the administration was amenable to talks that appear in the offing between U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar and Iraqi officials. ``We wouldn't have any problem with that,'' Scowcroft said. He also said the United States has no problem entering talks with the Iraqi leader, but he maintained the same hard-line position on conditions for such talks: Saddam must withdraw his forces from Kuwait and allow the emir of Kuwait to return to power. ``You have to make a distinction between being willing to talk to him and changing the conditions under which we're operating,'' Scowcroft said. ``That we're not willing to do.'' Bush's recreation-filled Sunday launched a week in which he planned to devote energies to the Middle East, including a congressional briefing Tuesday in Washington. Bush planned to consult Monday with Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, who was bringing his family to Walker's Point for an overnight stay. Canada is among the 22 nations providing forces to the multinational effort in the Persian Gulf. After Mulroney's departure, Bush was to fly to Washington to fill in key members of Congress on his Persian Gulf strategy. While administration officials say they have been in frequent contact with members of Congress since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, this would be the first time Bush has held such a face-to-face session with lawmakers on the gulf crisis. Bush's press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, said several members of Congress had requested the briefing, even though Congress still is in recess. Fitzwater told reporters that Mulroney ``has many contacts in the Arab world, and discussions he would also like to explore.'' Mulroney, a frequent confidant of Bush, and his family also visited the Bushes in Kennebunkport last summer.

DOC.HEAD: KGB Official Says Spy Agency's Mission is Protecting Perestroika
DOC.TEXT: A top KGB official Sunday disclosed the espionage arrests of some high-ranking Soviet officials in recent years and paid grudging tribute to the CIA as a crafty and determined adversary. In the interview in the Communist Party newspaper Pravda, the KGB official, Victor F. Grushko, also said the duty of the once-feared secret police is to protect perestroika, Mikhail S. Gorbachev's policy of political and economic reform. Interviews with top KGB officials were once extremely rare, but they have been appearing in print and even on television recently as part of a campaign to revamp the spy agency's image. These days, the KGB emphasizes its role in fighting corruption and foreign intelligence agencies. It has been playing down its history of terrorizing Soviet dissidents, tapping telephones and carrying out the late dictator Josef Stalin's purges. Grushko said that since 1985, the KGB had arrested more than 30 ``extremely dangerous'' spies. Virtually all were tried and shot, he said. Those arrested included Maj. Gen. Polyakov, a former top officer in the counterintelligence department of the Soviet General Staff, he said. Polyakov, whose first name was not given, would have been one of the highest-ranking Soviet spies in history. Grushko _ head of the KGB's second chief directorate, which is responsible for counterintelligence _ said Polyakov had ``handed over important information on the activities of our military intelligence.'' The KGB official boasted that the Soviet spy agency has stopped more than 120 attempts to relay secrets to Western intelligence services in the past five years. Other than Polyakov, other alleged spies identified by Grushko were A.G. Tolkachev, an engineer in the Radio Industry Ministry; a KGB agent identified only as Vorontsov; and a scientific worker at the Institute of the U.S.A. and Canada identified only as Potashov. The article did not provide any details on their arrests or what they were alleged to have done. Jeffrey T. Richelson, an American who has written about the KGB, said in a telephone interview from Washington that Tolkachev's arrest and execution previously have been made public, but that the other cases may be coming to light for the first time. Richelson, author of ``Sword and Shield,'' a 1986 book about Soviet intelligence operations, said Polyakov may have been a CIA source previously known by the code name ``Donald.'' The author also said he believed that Potashov had not previously been named, although it was known that there had been an espionage case at the U.S.A. and Canada Institute, a leading research center in Moscow. In the interview, Grushko also discussed the operations of CIA agents in Moscow, describing the tools of their trade, including miniature shortwave radio transmitters, tiny cameras, secret message containers that look like pebbles, invisible ink and an array of disguises. ``For example, an attache of the American Embassy _ a man with a fairly large build _ went on one operation artfully dressed in women's clothing,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Graves in West German Jewish Cemetery Desecrated
DOC.TEXT: Vandals overturned gravestones and painted slogans and swastikas in a Jewish cemetery, a police spokesman said Sunday. The vandalizing of the cemetery in the southwestern town of Freiburg was the fourth such incident in a month in the West German state of Baden-Wuerttemberg. Werner Erlach, a police spokesman in Freiburg, said the vandalism occurred overnight Saturday and was discovered by passersby on Sunday. He said police had no suspects. In similar incidents in recent weeks, 177 gravestones were overturned and damaged in the small town of Ihringen, about 12 miles from Freiburg. Slogans were also painted in Jewish cemeteries in Tuebingen and Stuttgart, two other towns in Baden-Wuerttemberg, Erlach said. No one was caught. In recent months, an outbreak of such desecrations in Jewish cemeteries in West Germany, France and other countries has raised fears of a wave of anti-Semitism.

DOC.HEAD: Guerrillas Claim To Repulse Government Offensive in Cambodia
DOC.TEXT: Cambodian guerrillas Sunday claimed they repulsed a large-scale offensive by that country's Communist government. Troops backed by multiple rocket launchers and Soviet-made T54 tanks struck guerrilla defense lines early Saturday morning, said a statement from Ok Serei Sopheak, a spokesman for the Khmer People's National Liberation Front. ``The front lines remain stable but still tense,'' said the statement from Ok Serei Sopheak, who had generally proved reliable in the past. The non-communist liberation front, led by former Cambodian Prime Minister Son Sann, is one of three guerrilla groups fighting the government Vietnam installed after invading Cambodia in late 1978. The statement said the guerrillas repulsed troops who attacked near Sisophon, a strategic crossroads town in Battambang province and about 30 miles east of the Thai border. ``After two hours, enemy forces retreated back without any success,'' it said. ``We maintain all our positions in the south.'' Attacking government troops were also driven off near Svay Chek, a town about 15 miles north of Sisophon, and Ta Vong, 17 miles southeast of Thmar Puok, a district capital in western Cambodia. Peace talks between the government and the three-party guerrilla coalition have been stalled by quarrels over who should rule Cambodia in the period before a general election. The other rebel groups are non-communist followers of former Cambodian head of state Prince Norodom Sihanouk and the Khmer Rouge, a Communist group that has the most powerful insurgent army. Under leader Pol Pot, the Khmer Rouge killed hundreds of thousands of people when it ruled Cambodia from 1975 until Vietnam's invasion ousted it. In an interview carried by the official Radio Hanoi on Saturday, Vietnam's Foreign Minister Nguyen Co Thach said Cambodia was capable of holding free elections as Nicaragua did recently. He reiterated that dissolution of the Vietnamese-installed government before an election would only bring chaos and thus facilitate a Khmer Rouge attempt to restore its brutal regime. ``The general elections in Nicaragua, all organized by the existing administrations under the supervision of the United Nations and foreign countries, were recognized by the world as truly free, democratic and fair,'' Thach said. ``Obviously, the same thing can be done in Cambodia.'' A text of the Thach interview was seen Sunday in Bangkok.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms Across Much of Nation
DOC.TEXT: Thunderstorms brought high winds and heavy rain to much of the nation Sunday while especially hot weather continued in parts of the Midwest and Texas. Hail the size of golf balls fell near Minnewaukan, Minn., and one-inch hail hit Isabel, S.D., the National Weather Service reported. Winds gusted to 100 mph near La Crosse, Wis. and to about 60 mph at Mobridge, S.D., Rochester, Minn. and Deforest, Wis. There was some storm damage in those states, the weather service said. Afternoon rainshowers and thunderstorms continued over lower Michigan, southern Wisconsin and northern Illinois as well as across western Arkansas and from western Montana into northern Idaho. Rain reached over the Florida panhandle and along the coast across Georgia, South Carolina, North Carolina and central Virginia. In Texas, Corpus Christi reached 101 degrees, a record high for the date. It was 100 degrees in Lake Charles, La., also a record. Unseasonably hot weather extended over much of Kansas, and was forecast to continue. The overnight low for Concordia, Kan. was 78 degrees, its warmest low for the date. Hot weather prevailed over much of the central and southern Plains as well as most of the Mississippi Valley. In Alaska, a storm moved over the Chukchi Sea and spread rain across the north part of the state. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 51 degrees at Mount Shasta, Calif. to 103 degrees at Medicine Lodge, Kan. Low temperature for the nation this morning was 31 degrees at Gunnison, Colo.

DOC.HEAD: Angolan Revolution Leader Mario Pinto de Andrade Dies
DOC.TEXT: Angolan writer and politician Mario Pinto de Andrade, a pioneer in Angola's struggle against Portuguese colonial rule, died Sunday in London after a long illness. He was 62. Although he dropped out of Angolan politics in the mid-1970s, Pinto de Andrade remained an influential figure in the war-torn southern African country. Pinto de Andrade became the first president of the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola in 1960, just before the Marxist group launched its 15-year guerrilla war to end Portuguese colonial rule. In 1974, he split with the Popular Movement, which came to power the following year when Angola became independent. Since 1975, Pinto de Andrade lived mainly in Guinea-Bissau. Both the Popular Movement government and the U.S.-backed UNITA rebels tried unsuccessfully to win his support in the continuing civil war that followed Angolan independence. Recently, he worked with other Popular Movement veterans in an effort to mediate the conflict. His brother Joaquim Pinto de Andrade leads an independent human rights group in Angola. The nationalist's death came as delegations from the government and UNITA, the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, arrived in Lisbon for talks aimed at reaching a cease-fire in the 15-year-old civil war. Pinto de Andrade was born in 1928 in the northern Angolan town of Golungo Alto and attended high school in the capital, Luanda. He studied classical philosophy at Lisbon University. In Lisbon in the 1950s, he worked with other African nationalists from Portuguese-speaking Africa, including the poet Agostinho Neto, who became Angola's first president, and Amilcar Cabral, who led Guinea-Bissau's struggle for independence in the 1960s. They tried to promote African culture and nationalist ideas in Portugal's five African colonies _ Angola, Mozambique, Guinea-Bissau, Cape Verde and Sao Tome e Principe. Pinto de Andrade edited an anthology of Portuguese African poetry that was published in 1969, which helped widen international awareness of the culture and provided a focus for young African intellectuals. After he split with the Popular Movement and left Angola in 1974, Pinto de Andrade worked for the government of newly-independent Guinea-Bissau as general secretary of the National Cultural Council. In 1980, he was appointed Guinea-Bissau's representative on the Executive Council of UNESCO. His last book, a history of the nationalist movements in Portuguese-speaking Africa, is due to be published soon. There was no immediate information on his survivors or funeral arrangements.

DOC.HEAD: Veteran Oklahoma City Journalist Dies at 67
DOC.TEXT: Stella Mae Roberts, a longtime reporter with The Associated Press and the first woman to be national secretary-treasurer of the Wire Service Guild, died at age 67 after a lengthy illness. An Oklahoma City funeral parlor said she died Saturday but did not give an exact cause of death. Ms. Roberts joined the AP in Oklahoma City in 1945 and worked there 31 years, much of that time in the Capitol bureau. After retiring in 1976, she became public information director of the Oklahoma Employment Security Commission. In 1964 Ms. Roberts was elected secretary-treasurer of Wire Service Guild, Local 222 of The Newspaper Guild, representing 2,300 employees of the AP and United Press International. She held the position two years. In 1970, Ms. Roberts received a double honor from the group Women in Communications. She was given the Byliners Award from the Oklahoma City professional chapter and was named Woman of the Year by the student chapter at the University of Oklahoma. Ms. Roberts was inducted into the Oklahoma Journalism Hall of Fame in 1984. Survivors include a niece, Joanna Roberts Chandler of Austin, Texas, and nephews Jim Roberts of San Antonio and Rob Parr of Oklahoma City, and several cousins. A prayer vigil is scheduled at 7 p.m. Monday at an Oklahoma City funeral home. A burial Mass will be held 10 a.m. Tuesday at St. Francis of Assisi Catholic Church with burial in Rose Hill Burial Park.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Reports Regulator Raised Money for Senator
DOC.TEXT: The federal regulator who oversaw Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan solicited campaign money for a congressman charged with supervision of the S&L industry, a newspaper reported Sunday. The Denver Post said Kermit Mowbray, former president of the Federal Home Loan Bank of Topeka, Kan., solicited campaign funds from other regulators for former Sen. David Karnes, R-Neb., then a member of the U.S. Senate Banking Committee. Karnes was chairman of the Topeka bank before being appointed to the Senate in 1987 when Democrat Ed Zorinsky died. He ran unsuccessfully for the seat in 1988. Karnes said he was unaware of campaign contributions from Mowbray and other regulators. Edwin Gray, former chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, which in turn governed the Topeka bank, said Mowbray's fund-raising ``shows very poor judgment. It's dead wrong.'' ``If there was any kind of coercion, I would say that it is at the least highly improper and possibly a violation of the law,'' Gray said. Federal law prohibits government employees from raising money for federal campaigns, but does not apply to Home Loan Bank employees. Mowbray gave $2,000 to Karnes' campaign in June 1987 and suggested to presidents of the Home Loan Bank system's 12 regional banks that they also contribute. ``I didn't see anything wrong with that,'' Mowbray told the Post. The bailout of the nationwide savings and loan industry is expected to cost taxpayers at least $500 billion. The objectivity of thrift regulators has become an issue in the Silverado case largely because President Bush's son, Neil, was a director of the Denver thrift, which failed at a cost of $1 billion to taxpayers. Last month, the Treasury Department began investigating allegations that Mowbray deliberately postponed seizing Silverado until after the 1988 presidential election to protect Bush from bad publicity. Mowbray told the House Banking Committee in June that he received a telephone call from Washington in October 1988 ordering the delay. The thrift was seized in December 1988, after the November presidential election. He said he did not remember who made the call. Shortly after Silverado failed, Mowbray left his job at the Topeka bank. During his tenure, Karnes was a bank board member along with Silverado chairman Michael Wise, who donated $2,000 to Karnes' campaign. As a member of the Senate Banking Committee, Karnes proposed the ``Thrift Charter Enhancement Act of 1988,'' which sought to create incentives for investors to place additional capital in the thrift industry. Federal election records also show that Thurman Connell, president of the Federal Home Loan Bank of Des Moines and Brian Dittenhaufer, president of the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York, each gave $500 to Karnes' campaign. Karnes said last week he never discussed Neil Bush or Silverado with Mowbray.

DOC.HEAD: Perez de Cuellar To Meet Iraqi Foreign Minister
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with Aziz comment, Kuwaiti reax; pickup 6th graf `On Saturday...'
DOC.TEXT: Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar will meet Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz this week to discuss the Persian Gulf crisis, U.N. and Iraqi officials said Sunday. The meeting will be the United Nation's first formal attempt to mediate the international dispute. The secretary-general will meet with Aziz on Thursday in the Jordanian capital, Amman, ``in order to engage in a full exchange of views on the crisis,'' said U.N. spokeswoman Nadia Younes. She said she could not say whether any other leaders would attend the meeting. ``We're not ruling anything out,'' she said. The crisis was set off by Iraq's invasion and annexation of Kuwait, which has been condemned by the United Nations in a series of resolutions. The latest came Saturday with support for military enforcement of the U.N. embargo against Iraq. U.S. and other warships have assembled in the Persian Gulf region since the crisis began. American planes and thousands of troops have been rushed to Saudi Arabia, which borders Kuwait. Aziz said in Baghdad on Sunday that he planned to meet with Perez de Cuellar this week, but he did not elaborate. He declined to say whether Iraq was prepared to compromise on Kuwait's status, but he said his country would listen to any proposal. ``We are open to listen to suggestions,'' Aziz said in an interview with CNN. ``We have not closed the door to any idea. But this question is complicated by the American threat to Iraq.'' Aziz called the United Nations ``a pawn'' of the United States and said other countries voted for U.N. resolutions against Iraq because they ``were under severe pressure from the United States.'' Kuwait's U.N. ambassador, Mohammad A. Abulhasan, said he did not foresee a breakthrough in the planned meeting. In an interview, the envoy said Perez de Cuellar was only to gather information. ``I don't expect him to negotiate with Iraq,'' Abulhasan said. On Saturday, Perez de Cuellar said in Bogota, Colombia, that he had invited the Iraqi minister to meet to discuss the situation. Ms. Younes would not comment on Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's statement Saturday that he would welcome a visit by the U.N. chief. Saddam's statement came in Baghdad, where he was was asked by reporters traveling with Austrian President Kurt Waldheim whether he would agree to meet with the U.N. secretary-general in Iraq. ``Of course,'' Saddam replied, ``The U.N. secretary-general is always welcome.'' He was quoted by the official Iraqi News Agency. The news agency said Saddam was referring to Perez de Cuellar _ not Waldheim, the former secretary-general _ but provided no further details. Saddam's news conference came at the end of a one-day visit by Waldheim, who flew out of Baghdad with about 100 Austrian nationals who had been stranded in the country. Perez de Cuellar made his offer hours after the U.N. Security Council authorized the use of military force to enforce the trade embargo against Iraq to punish Saddam for his Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. ``I believe that after the resolutions adopted by the Security Council, the time has come for the secretary-general to begin diplomatic efforts to alleviate the present crisis in the gulf in all aspects, through the process of dialogue,'' the secretary-general said. In Kennebunkport, Maine, White House spokesman Roman Popadiuk said Saturday that Washington welcomes a ``discussion by all U.N. members in the context of the complete and immediate and unconditional withdrawal'' of Iraqi forces from Kuwait. Saddam has repeatedly refused to withdraw from Kuwait, which Iraq annexed six days after the invasion.

DOC.HEAD: Nobel Laurate at Hate Conference Demands Iraq Free Hostages
DOC.TEXT: Nobel Peace Prize winner Elie Wiesel, opening an international conference on ways to counter hate, appealed to Iraq on Sunday to free thousands of trapped foreigners. ``Our thoughts go to the most recent victims and prisoners of hate _ those who are being used and manipulated in Kuwait and Iraq,'' Wiesel said in his opening remarks. ``In the name of humanity, we appeal for their unconditional and immediate release,'' said Wiesel, the Romanian-born author and human rights activist. ``A human being is not a shield,'' he said, referring to Iraq's move to place scores of foreigners at military and industrial sites as human shields to deter any U.S. air strikes. The four-day conference on ``The Anatomy of Hate''has attracted about 70 participants from 30 countries _ including world statesmen, Nobel laureates, thinkers and activists. Among those scheduled to attend are South African anti-apartheid activist Nelson Mandela; Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel, a former dissident playwright; French President Francois Mitterrand, and Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis. Wiesel, the Nazi death camp survivor who won the 1986 Nobel Peace Prize for his work exposing the horrors of the Holocaust, organized the conference with the Oslo-based Nobel Peace Prize committee to discuss the problem of hate. Last fall, when he issued the call to attend the conference, Wiesel said he feared that the new freedoms won by East bloc nations would cause smoldering religious, ethnic and regional hatred to flare. Now, he said, he wishes that the conference could have been held six months ago, when it might have helped relax tensions in such hotspots of conflict as the Persian Gulf and South Africa. ``Hate, as we know, wears many masks,'' said Wiesel, 61, who is now a U.S. citizen and Boston University professor. He asked participants to expose various forms of hatred: ``racial hate, religious hate, ethnic hate, fanaticism, bigotry, prejudice and discrimination.'' Wiesel said he hoped the seminar would end with some kind of joint declaration. Yelena Bonner, the Soviet human rights activist and widow of the 1975 Nobel Peace Prize laureate Andrei Sakharov, said the participants must first admit ``that hate is an emotion given us by God.'' ``Our conference is opening at time that is not the best for calm and clear reason. ... After the August 2 invasion (of Kuwait), we are living in a very different reality,'' she said, speaking through an interpreter. Ms. Bonner said years of arms sales by the Soviet Union and France to ``a known assassin'' like Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein prove that firm international rules, and not just debates about morals, are needed to protect human rights. On Monday, Mandela is scheduled to open a discussion on apartheid, South Africa's system of racial separation. Others attending the conference are Harvard economist John Kenneth Galbraith, actor Gregory Peck, former President Jimmy Carter and Chai Ling, a leader of last year's pro-democracy movement in Beijing.

DOC.HEAD: Lujan: Timber Job Losses Will Be Minimized Under Spotted-Owl Plan
DOC.TEXT: Timber industry job losses will be far less than originally thought under a plan to protect the spotted owl on Forest Service land in the Pacific Northwest, Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan said Sunday. Lujan and Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter are facing a Saturday deadline to report to President Bush with a plan to protect the owl, as required under the federal Endangered Species Act. ``Environmentalists are not going to like it, but you have to have balance,'' Lujan told reporters. ``You can't throw 21,000 people out of work and not give it consideration ... I fully expect one side or the other to sue me over the plan.'' A recommendation by Forest Service biologist Jack Ward Thomas would ban logging on 3 million acres of Northwest forests currently open to timber harvests. The government has estimated the move would reduce federal harvests in the region by nearly 50 percent at a cost of more than 20,000 jobs by the end of the decade. Lujan, while declining to say how the plan might be altered in terms of acreage, said job losses probably would be scaled down. ``That's my aim,'' he said, ``to come out with a substantial reduction in job loss.'' Lujan conceded the spotted owl needs plenty of old-growth forest to survive, but questioned whether it needs as much as environmentaists think. ``I found an owl last week in Oregon and it wasn't in old-growth timber,'' he said. ``So it showed me that the owls can live outside of old-growth areas.'' Lujan was taken by Bureau of Land Management officials on a tour last week of a forest 10 miles northeast of Eugene, Ore., where he got a clear look at a male spotted owl. But officials there said the owl lived in old-growth forest. Later, at a Republican fund-raiser here, Lujan renewed his criticism of the Endangered Species Act, saying it has become a tool for environmentalists to block economic development and multiple use of public lands. ``In some cases, a particular listing may threaten the jobs of thousands, throwing entire communities or regions into economic and social turmoil,'' he said. ``We must work to ensure that a balance is reached between our desire to preserve species, while also preserving the livelihoods of our citizens.'' In June, Lujan wondered in a published interview if endangered species must be protected in every locale where they exist. ``Do we have to save every subspecies?'' Lujan said. His statement drew the ire of conservationists who insist that the loss of any genetically distinct subspecies poses a potentially dire threat to the environment. The government gave permission to the University of Arizona last week to proceed with construction of a $200 million observatory that some say could threaten the habitat of the endangered Mount Graham red squirrel.

DOC.HEAD: Driver Uninjured in Fiery Tanker Crash
DOC.TEXT: A tanker truck carrying 8,650 gallons of gasoline overturned and exploded Sunday on a bridge over the Deschutes River, but its driver walked away uninjured, police said. The accident closed for several hours the Interstate 84 bridge, about seven miles east of this northern Oregon city. The highway is the main road link between eastern and western Oregon. Burning gasoline dropped into the Deschutes River but it burned or evaporated quickly and did not pose an environmental hazard, officials said. Police Sgt. Stephen White identified the driver as Christopher Mark Haberstich, who worked for Russell Oil Co. of Boardman.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq's Neighbors Move to Ease Refugee Passage
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with Pakistanis crossing into Iran; new reports of evacuees arriving in Jordan; ADDS quotes from Briton who escaped into Syria; CORRECTS that Iran borders Iraq to east sted north; minor editing; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's neighbors moved Sunday to ease passage for refugees of the Persian Gulf conflict, in some cases setting aside disputes among themselves to do so. Israel plans to ease restrictions at its only border crossing with Jordan _ which borders Iraq _ to assist those fleeing the gulf region, officials in Jerusalem said Sunday. Tehran radio, monitored in Nicosia, quoted Iran's foreign minister as saying foreigners fleeing Iraq and Kuwait can do so via Iran, which borders Iraq to the east. Later, Tehran radio said more than 3,000 Pakistanis who had been living in Kuwait had crossed into Iran along its border with Turkey. But it was not clear whether the Iranian promise, which came at the request of the Philippines, applied to Westerners, or was confined to Asians and Arabs. Jordan and Turkey, which have been the prime escape routes for foreigners so far, have complained they are overburdened by thousands of refugees and have threatened to close their borders unless they received international help to cope with the influx. Such aid has begun to flow. Most of the people who have fled since Iraq invaded its oil-rich neighbor Kuwait on Aug. 2 have gone by way of Jordan, which has been forced to feed and shelter thousands until they could afford to continue on to their home countries. A Jordanian border official at Ruweishid, 210 miles northeast of Amman, said 5,000 people, mostly Egyptians, crossed there from Iraq on Sunday morning. On Saturday, more than 13,000 people entered Jordan at Ruweishid, he said. Nearly all of these refugees are Arabs or Asians. A group of 31 Westerners _ including French, British and U.S. citizens _ arrived in Jordan from Iraq on Sunday. All of the Americans were of Arab extraction, a senior Jordanian official said. Syria, Iraq's main Arab rival, announced Saturday it would allow foreigners to cross its border with Iraq for humanitarian reasons. The border has been closed since 1981. Martin Watts, a Briton who arrived Saturday in Syria after fleeing across the desert with six other Britons and an Australian, said the group fled after deciding it was better to face hostile border guards than remain in Baghdad and risk being detained. ``We decided we all preferred risking bullets while escaping to remaining in Iraq and risking chemical weapons,'' said Watts, an engineer who like his companions worked for a British company building a power station near Baghdad. ``We told people we were going to Baghdad for a beer, boarded our trucks, carried a map and our passports and drove west across the desert'' for 43 hours, Watts said. The coordinator of Israel's occupied territories, Shmuel Goren, said on Israel radio Sunday that the government was easing restrictions on crossing the Allenby Bridge on the Israeli-Jordanian frontier. He cited humanitarian reasons. Normally, tourists who want to cross between Jordan and the occupied West Bank via the Allenby bridge must make arrangements ahead of time. Last week, an agreement that would have allowed tens of thousands of Egyptian refugees passage home through Israel was scrapped after it was leaked to the press, embarrassing the Jordanian and Egyptian governments. Jordan is officially in a state of war with Israel. Egypt is the only Arab state to have made peace with Israel and is sensitive to suggestions it is too close to the Jewish state. Most of the refugees crossing into Jordan are Arabs, but some have been Westerners. There are about 840,000 Palestinians working in the Persian Gulf region, and many of those in Iraq and Kuwait are now fleeing. Others in oil-rich gulf nations such as Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates fear a backlash against Palestinians for their support of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. Normally, Palestinians without Israeli-issued identity cards seeking to visit the occupied territories must wait for permission from the Israeli authorities. ``It can usually take up to four weeks for their security clearance to come through, and they can then only stay up to three months,'' an Israeli government source said. ``Now, we are doing everything we can to make the process as quick as possible, and we will allow them to extend their stay on a case-by-case basis,'' he said. The government also was dropping the requirement that men between 16 and 35 who leave the territories must stay away for more than nine months, the source said. That rule is designed to allow students to go abroad but prevent Palestinian activists making frequent trips in which they could carry messages back and forth.

DOC.HEAD: Free Video Time For Gulf Messages
DOC.TEXT: A cable company is producing free 30-second video greetings from family and friends of soldiers deployed to the Middle East, and the military has agreed to broadcast them to U.S. ships in the Persian Gulf. Arrangements are underway to have the ``Cable Grams From Home'' broadcast to troops on land also, said Edward K. Conklin, spokesman for Jones' Intercable Inc. The company will produce the videos this week at its 10 studios in suburban Chicago, he said. ``We know people who have not had the chance to say goodbye to family and friends,'' Conklin said. ``We had one lady who was contacted and all she got was a call from a computer that the private so-and-so had been shipped to the Persian Gulf and no other information was available.''

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Flap Causes German Politicians to Disagree on Unity Treaty
DOC.TEXT: Sharp differences over abortion regulations kept West German political leaders from forging a consensus Monday on a treaty to merge the country's laws with those of East Germany. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and top members of his conservative coalition met for four hours until early Monday morning with leaders of the opposition Social Democrats in an effort to ensure smooth passage for the treaty in the legislature. But Oskar Lafontaine, the Social Democratic candidate who will oppose Kohl for chancellor in all-German elections scheduled for December, said after the meeting in Bonn that differences remained on the abortion issue. The left-of-center Social Democrats are incensed at a government decision that West German women who try to take advantage of East Germany's more liberal abortion law after unification can be prosecuted. As a result, the Social Democrats have threatened to block adoption of the unity treaty, which needs a two-thirds vote to pass in the Parliament. The treaty will cover various issues, including distribution of sales tax revenues among the German states, how to settle claims by West Germans seeking the return of their former property in East Germany, and abortion. Failure to pass the treaty would not jeopardize the Oct. 3 date set for the unification of the two German states. But it would mean that most West German laws would go into force in East Germany after unity takes place, a move East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere has said would not serve the best interests of his compatriots. East Germans are increasingly unsettled by the prospect of simply being absorbed by their richer neighbor and having to adjust to an entirely new economic and legal system. Politicians in both countries, women's groups and government officials have been debating for weeks over the best abortion law for a united Germany. While the Social Democrats are pro-choice, Kohl's conservative Christian Democrats support restrictions on a woman's right to an abortion. East German women have a legal right to an abortion within the first 12 weeks of pregnancy. But the West German law is much more restrictive. West German women must prove the pregnancy is life-threatening, resulted from rape or incest, or would create severe social and economic hardships. Participants in the Bonn meeting called by Kohl are to meet again on Wednesday for further talks on the treaty. They did agree that an all-German parliament should adopt rules governing abortion that would apply throughout the country. Elections for the all-German legislature are set for Dec. 2.

DOC.HEAD: Buddhist Church Members Confirm First Western Leader Dead From AIDS
DOC.TEXT: Vajra Regent Osel Tendzin, the first Westerner to lead an international Tibetan Buddhist sect, has died from an AIDS-related illness, members of the religious group said Sunday. He was 47. Tendzin, born Thomas Rich, died Saturday of respiratory failure at Pacific Presbyterian Medical Center in San Francisco, according to members of the Boulder, Colo.-based Dharmadatu Buddhist church called Vajradhatu. Julie Murray, spokeswoman for the hospital, could not confirm his death, saying no one was registered under the Tendzin or Rich names. ``A lot of members had difficulty accepting that he was sick,'' said one of the church members, who refused to give his name. ``It's been quite difficult for a lot of students of our church. There have been a lot of different versions of reality.'' Tendzin was reportedly admitted to the hospital in mid-August. He was raised in Passaic, N.J. After dropping out of Fordham University, he met the Venerable Chogyam Trungpa in 1971 and became the Tibetan Buddhist leader's top student. Trungpa gave him the name Osel Tendzin, or ``radiant holder of the teachings.'' Vajradhatu was founded by Trungpa, who had fled the Chinese invasion of Tibet to settle in Boulder. Trungpa also founded the Naropa Institute, an accredited liberal arts college combining Eastern and Western studies. In 1976, Trungpa named Tendzin as his successor, the first time a Westerner had achieved such a position in the Tibetan Buddhist tradition. Trungpa died in 1987 at the age of 47. In December 1988, Tendzin told Vajradhatu members in San Francisco that he had contracted AIDS. There were reports at the time he also had acknowledged putting others at risk through his sexual behavior. The revelation tore the organization apart, with supporters insisting Tendzin should remain as the group's leader and critics arguing he must resign because he had betrayed the trust of followers. The Buddhist church's board of directors, who wrested leadership of the group from Tendzin, were meeting this weekend at Karmecholing, a meditation center in Barnet, Vt.

DOC.HEAD: Three American Dependents Stopped at Iraq-Turkish Border
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 5th graf prv, ``The spokeswoman xxx to note that all 55 U.S. dependents previously described as women and children; and inserts grafs 8-9, ``In a telephone xxx with further detail from telephone interview
DOC.TEXT: Fifty-two of 55 dependents of U.S. Embassy personnel from Kuwait crossed from Iraq into Turkey late Sunday, but three males were detained by Iraqi border authorities, the State Department said. A spokeswoman for the Kuwait task force at State Department headquarters said, ``The convoy of Kuwait embassy dependents crossed the border from Iraq into Turkey about 2 a.m. Iraqi time (6 p.m. EDT.). Fifty-two of the group of 55 who earlier had permission to cross were allowed to leave. ``Three young men in the group, male dependents of Kuwait embassy diplomats, were not allowed by Iraqi officials to transit the border and are in the company of an American Embassy Bagdad escort officer. ``The 52 were met by a party from the American Embassy in Ankara. They will rest tonight in Turkey and plans are being made for their en route journey home.'' The spokeswoman, who declined to allow her name to be used, said she had no information on the ages of the three males held back, nor on what would happen to them. State Department officials previously have described all 55 of the dependents as ``women and children.'' She likewise had no details on the whereabouts of the 52 allowed to cross other than that they were in safe hands had were moved some distance away from the border in buses to spend the rest of the night. The announcement from the State Department came a few hours after an ABC News report that a bus carrying the Americans had been turned back at the border, leaving U.S. officials waiting in Turkey uncertain for a time as to what was happening. In a telephone interview with AP Broadcast from Diyarbakir, Turkey, David Kostelancik, vice consul of the U.S. Embassy in Ankara, Turkey, said the 52 dependents ``were received by the American consul from Adana, Mr. Harry Cole, and at a later time transportation was arranged for them from the border to Dyarbakir.'' ``They were all very, very tired but they were all very enthusiastic, very happy to be in Turkey,'' said Kostelancik. ``They will be transported sometime today (Monday) to the Interlik air base near Adana, where they will remain and they will probably leave sometime tomorrow (Tuesday) for the United States.'' The crossing occurred, as previously planned, at Habur. Meanwhile, national security adviser Brent Scowcroft said Sunday that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, faced with increasing global opposition to his conquest of Kuwait, is now intent on seeking a way out of the ``box'' he is in. Scowcroft and a variety of other experts interviewed Sunday all indicated there was room for hope that the 24-day-old Persian Gulf crisis could be resolved short of military conflict. ``I can see a peaceful way out of it,'' Scowcroft said on ABC-TV's ``This Week With David Brinkley'' program. ``Saddam Hussein must now see he's facing overwhelming world opinion.'' ``He is casting about for a way out of the box in which he finds himself,'' Scowcroft said. The pressure on Saddam appeared to increase dramatically Saturday when the U.N. Security Council gave the United States and other nations the right to use military power in enforcing the economic embargo against Iraq. Scowcroft said Saddam has shown himself in the past to be a realist, citing his willingness two weeks ago to bow to Iran's terms for a settlement of their eight-year war. Among other concessions, Saddam agreed to recognize the prewar boundary of the two countries. Meanwhile, State Department press officer Anita Stockman said Sunday the U.S. Embassy in Iraqi-occupied Kuwait has been informed that two additional Americans have been taken into custody by Iraqi troops. She said the information was relayed to the embassy by telephone. Although officials had no way of confirming the information, she said embassy personnel had reason to believe it was accurate. She had no additional details about those arrested. Assistant Secretary of State for Near East and South Asian Affairs John Kelly said little had changed at the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait City, which, along with a number of other Western diplomatic missions, was being surrounded by Iraqi troops. Appearing on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press'' program, Kelly said the embassy is hampered in its efforts to help the estimated 2,500 Americans whom Iraq is refusing permission to leave the country. He said less than 10 have been picked up by Iraqi troops. Another 50 are in Iraqi troop custody in Baghdad, he said. Iraq cut off electricity at the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait on Saturday and the power remained off Sunday. The embassy was using a power generator. Iraqi troops were preventing anyone from entering or leaving the embassy but Kelly said the reduced staff there probably had a couple of weeks worth of supplies remaining. At the Pentagon, the Army on Sunday ordered 50 more Army reserve and National Guard units in 25 states to report for active duty by Aug. 31. The Defense Department also said elements of the Army's 13th Support Command at Fort Hood, Texas, had begun to deploy to the Middle East. The impetus for a diplomatic solution appeared to increase when Iraqi Ambassador Mohamed al-Mashat said his government would welcome a mediation effort by U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar. Perez de Cuellar said Saturday he was seeking an urgent meeting this week with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz in either New York or Geneva. After his television appearance, Scowcroft said the administration ``would have no problem'' with a mediation by Perez de Cuellar. He added that highest U.S. priority was inducing Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. After that, he said, ``We're prepared to talk about anything.'' Scowcroft was interviewed in Kennebunkport, Maine, where he was staying with the vacationing President Bush. The president, who played golf and tennis and received a briefing from Scowcroft, continued to refuse to answer reporters' questions about the gulf situation. Bush was to return to Washington on Tuesday to brief congressional leaders on the gulf crisis. Al-Mashat, appearing on CBS-TV's ``Face the Nation'' program, contrasted Iraq's ``desire for peace'' with the American ``design to have war.'' He said America's aggressive intentions were clearly demonstrated by the dispatch of offensive weaponry, including stealth bombers, to Saudi Arabia. The notion that the United States and Iraq were moving inevitably toward war was disputed on ABC by Henry A. Kissinger and Zbigniew Brzezinski, both former national security advisers. ``I believe that Saddam Hussein is looking for some way out,'' Kissinger said. ``If we stay firm ... we will get it.'' The under secretary of state for political affairs, Robert Kimmitt, said on CBS that Saddam's hand sooner or later will be forced by the economic sanctions approved by the U.N. Security Council.

DOC.HEAD: Monument Erected at Rumored Gravesite of Talking Horse
DOC.TEXT: About 200 people milled around Sunday under a wild cherry tree where Mr. Ed, the 1960s television star, is said to be buried. But there's no record of his death because Mr. Ed was a horse, of course. A 5-foot-tall granite monument, with a picture of the ``talking horse'' sticking his head out over a barn door as he did in the show, was unveiled on the farm of Danny and Darlene Snodgrass. When the Snodgrasses bought the 17-acre site north of Tahlequah in 1981, they didn't give much credence to a cousin's recollection of visiting the place as a youngster to see Mr. Ed. But other people around this northeastern Oklahoma town told the couple the same story. They learned that Clarence Tharp, whose family sold them the land, brought Mr. Ed to Tahlequah after the series was canceled. There are other versions of Mr. Ed's demise. One person associated with the show said the horse died in 1973 and was cremated, with his ashes spread over Hollywood, Mrs. Snodgrass said. Another said Mr. Ed died in 1968. But ``we feel pretty certain that it's Mr. Ed here,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Yacht with 17 People Aboard Found Adrift in Pacific
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with yacht found, crew safe
Eds: Monday cq in lead
DOC.TEXT: The Coast Guard found a yacht that had been crippled in rough seas southwest of Guam and sent a patrol boat Monday to tow the boat and its crew to safety, officials said. A C-130 search and rescue plane from Hawaii spotted the Royal Taipan about 120 miles east-northeast of Yap, an island of the Federated State of Micronesia, said Lt. Kent Youel, a Coast Guard spokesman in Honolulu. Earlier reports had said the 146-foot vessel was lost about 225 miles south-southwest of Guam, but its location Monday was about 500 miles southwest of Guam. A 95-foot patrol boat was sent out from Yap to take the boat in tow, Youel said. Everyone aboard was reported safe, he said. The Royal Taipan, a converted Navy minesweeper owned by Honolulu-based Windjammer Cruises, first radioed for help Saturday when it ran into the fringes of Tropical Storm Abe. Communication was lost Sunday night just after the crew reported that it was taking on water in 25-foot seas and about 50 mph winds, and that water had reached the floorboards, said Youel. The crew, including 14 Filipinos and two Americans, was sailing the Royal Taipan from the Philippines to Saipan, where the yacht was to have been refurbished for cruises, Youel said. The nationality of the 17th crewmember wasn't known.

Roughly 60,000 American soldiers, airmen and sailors have moved to battle stations in the Persian Gulf since President Bush ordered U.S. firepower into the area to thwart Iraq's Saddam Hussein, sources say. In addition to the massive troop movement, the Pentagon has built a virtual armada in the region's seas and rushed in hundreds of fighter jets and support aircraft. The deployment, the largest since the Vietnam War, is far from complete. Within a few weeks, about 45,000 Marines are expected to have arrived in the area. By then the total U.S. combat force in the region may number well over 100,000, military sources said last week.

U.S. forces in Saudi Arabia still lack ground-based anti-aircraft systems and other equipment considered vital for extended combat, field commanders say. ``We're pretty naked out here right now,'' an Air Force officer said during a recent visit to his desert base area. Commanders and supply officers characterized the equipment problems as serious but not severe, and attributed them to the limited transport capabilities of the U.S. military. Officials said many of the concerns should be addressed over the next week to 10 days, as more ships arrive. For the most part, the unprecedented air and sea lift of U.S. forces has proceeded smoothly.
