East Germany is about to disappear, to be swallowed up by its rich western neighbor, and the universal enthusiasm of a few months ago has waned. Polls say the vast majority of East Germans favor unification, which is barely a month away. But appearances don't always reinforce that conclusion. The ``We are one people'' banners that hung from trees, factories and homes during the pro-unity frenzy of early 1990 are gone. There are no cheering crowds and no convoys of motorists blasting their horns in anticipation of full unification on Oct. 3.

DOC.HEAD: Junk Defaults Rising, Outlook for Rest of Year Dim
DOC.TEXT: Junk bond defaults rose in the first half of 1990 and analysts say a weak economy and higher oil prices could bring the highest default rate in 20 years. As the economy slows and higher gasoline and heating oil prices leave consumers with less money to spend in casinos, department stores and on new homes, businesses will have less cash to make interest and principal payments. In the first seven months of the year, 32 high-yield bond issuers defaulted for an annualized rate of 5.8 percent, according to John Lonski, chief economists at Moody's Investor Service Inc. If maintained, the it would be the highest rate since the collapse of the Penn Central railroad accounted for a 10.9 percent default rate in 1970, Lonski said. ``I don't think we've passed the bottom yet in all likelihood, especially for the highly-leveraged firms that depend on descretionary income,'' Lonski said. Prices of issues expected to ride up and down with the business cycle have taken a pounding since oil prices rose after Iraq overran Kuwait on Aug. 2. Numbers compiled by Citicorp show total returns on junk bonds issued by recession-prone industries suffered the worst in the first half of August. Casinos dropped 7.8 percent, building materials fell 7.1 percent and retailers are off 3.6 percent. Toilet maker American Standard Inc., which relies heavily on energy in making ceramics as well as new homes for sales, saw its 12~-percent senior subordinated debentures that mature in the year 2000 skid from 93 to the high 80s last week. Junk bonds are debt securities typically issued by companies that lack investment grade credit. Often used to raise capital for expansion, they carry high interest rates to compensate for their risky nature. ``The market is reflecting fears of a recession. It was already worried about corporate profits weakening,'' said Mariel Clemensen, Citicorp's high-yield research director. A recession would hit steeply leveraged companies particularly hard, which have huge principal and interest payments among their fixed costs, Lonski said. When looking to cut expenses, capital spending and employment are likely to be hit harder than if a company didn't have a high debt obligation. Even industries such as food, tobacco and health care, whose fortunes tend to resist economic downturns, could be hurt as consumers resist price hikes that heavily indebted companies have relied upon to boost cash flow, Lonski said. Citicorp's numbers show total returns on health-care issues dropping 0.9 percent and broadcasting issues falling 1.7 percent in the first half of August. ``You might find some that will escape unscathed,'' Lonski said, particularly utilities that rely heavily on nuclear power to produce electricity. For utilities, junk bonds are usually so-called fallen angels, once highly rated issues that became viewed as risky the more they faced trouble with their investments in nuclear power. But these utilities' reliance on nuclear power is what may make some an attractive investment during a prolonged oil-price shock, Lonski said. Arizona Public Service Co. and Philadelphia Electric Co., for example, are two utilities with speculative-grade bonds that have substantial nuclear-power generating capabilities. Moreover, public sentiment about nuclear power could improve if the country once again starts looking to alternative fuel sources.

DOC.HEAD: No. 3 Long-Distance Company Dogged by Problems
DOC.TEXT: A month after reporting a shocking second quarter loss, US Sprint is airing new TV ads and strengthening its sales staff to grab business from the the nation's two largest long-distance companies. But many think Sprint, with 10 percent of the market, faces an uphill battle. It must compete for residential customers at a time when MCI Communications Corp. and American Telephone and Telegraph Co. have established strong telemarketing, sales and ad campaigns targeted toward the individual buyer. Sprint must cut costs at the same time. ``I think things are going to turn around for them,'' said Audrey Stevoff, vice president and telecommunications analyst for Duff & Phelps in Chicago. ``But I'm not sure how quickly. They can cut costs fairly easily. But getting customers onto your network _ that's the challenge.'' Other analysts think the $42 million loss that caused the stock of Sprint's parent company to plummet is a sign the fiercely competitive long-distance industry is stabilizing. ``Sprint was late to the dinner table, and it is just never going to have as large a portion of the pie,'' said Robert B. Morris III, analyst for Goldman, Sachs & Co. in San Francisco. ``You will have them as a viable third carrier, but they probably will never reach the levels of market share that MCI will reach.'' Partly, Morris says, that's because ``the gobs of market share that AT&T was losing at one point are no longer available.'' ``You had many investors working on the premise that Sprint was just MCI two years later,'' Morris said, and would grow just as big. MCI has about 14 percent of the market. Now that premise has been shaken, he contends. Sprint officials, for their part, say the market, analysts and the media overreacted to the loss they announced July 17. The loss caused second quarter earnings of United Telecommunications Inc. to fall 55 percent. It owns 80 percent of Sprint. The loss also delayed United Telecom's buyout of the remaining 20 percent of Sprint owned by the GTE Corp. of Stamford, Conn. The two companies formed Sprint in mid-1986. Sprint officials acknowledge costs were too high and revenue growth lower than expected. Basically, the company fell behind in the fight for residential customers, they say. It continues to sell well to businesses and is getting revenues from its share of a large government contract. ``We've said very clearly that we did not take action as soon as we could have in that part of the market,'' said Ron LeMay, Sprint's president and chief operating officer. ``We realize that we have to become more aggressive, and what you're seeing now in action is a reflection of that.'' Those actions include eliminating 1,300 jobs nationwide, mostly administrative jobs, and putting more people into marketing efforts, including sales and service jobs targeted toward smaller customers. In addition, new TV ads directly confront a recent AT&T charge that other long-distance companies won't put their promises in writing. ``It's an attempt to very clearly educate customers that we have the full range of long-distance possibilities, plus the service to back it up,'' LeMay said. Those are steps in the right direction, say analysts who contend Sprint simply lost track of what its competitors were doing. ``I think they thought their blanket commercial about the pin would reach all markets,'' Stevoff said. But MCI decided last fall to refocus on residential customers and began an intense telemarketing campaign. And AT&T blanketed television with commercials designed to attract ``the average Joe calling Aunt Sophie,'' Stevoff said. Morris worries that Sprint still is just reacting to the market instead of leading the way. ``These are things that will help you maintain your share,'' he said of the new ads. ``But if you're really going to accelerate things you have to lead the market, rather than follow it.'' Since the earnings announcement, Sprint officials also have reacted angrily to charges that the billing problems they struggled with in the late 1980s have recurred. Morris said he has heard of no new problems. The Federal Communications Commission says 376 written complaints about billing were filed against Sprint in the first 10 months of this fiscal year, vs. 821 last year. But Sprint does lag in development of the sophisticated billing systems that competitors are offering customers. ``Once again, it's just an extremely competitive atmosphere where they're struggling to keep up,'' Morris said.

DOC.HEAD: Bear Sightings on Wall Street
DOC.TEXT: The steep decline in stock prices this summer has left investors staring into the jaws of what some say may be Wall Street's first sustained bear market in nearly a decade. Today's generation of stock traders and analysts is by no means unaccustomed to to the phenomenon of falling markets. Most of them were around for the Crash of 1987, which provided all the conditions you could want for a baptimism of fire. That debacle produced a 36 percent drop in the Dow Jones industrial average, enough to rank prominently on any list of modern-day market declines. But almost all the carnage occurred in a span of less than two months, and stocks began to recover quickly thereafter en route to new highs. Many an investor, it appeared, was still numb from the shock when the wounds began to heal. For an undisputed example of the kind of long, debilitating slide for which classic bear markets are famous, one has to go back to 1981-82, before the big boom of the '80s on Wall Street was ready to start. From April 27, 1981 to Aug. 12, 1982, the Dow Jones industrials tumbled from 1,024.05 to 776.92 as the economy struggled through a recession exacerbated by rapid inflation and high interest rates. Instead of the sudden jolt of a crash, the market in those days experienced a kind of slow, steady erosion that gave investors plenty of time to think about how much money they were losing and how bleak the outlook seemed. The question of the moment now, of course, is whether stocks are in for a similar malaise, or just undergoing one of the periodic ``corrections'' that have punctuated the long bull market since '82. Simple to ask, not so easy to answer. Incipient bear markets are notoriously cunning at disguising themselves as short-term corrections, and vice versa. On the optimistic side, however, analysts point out that authentic bear markets have seldom begun with a single event that serves as an ``explanation'' for the decline _ in this case, Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Indeed, many veteran market-watchers worry more when declines set in that have no readily discernible cause. ``Past major confrontations such as the Cuban missile crisis or other military squabbles that were resolved favorably proved to be just a blip in the stock market's general trend,'' observes Greg Smith, an analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities. ``We could be in one of those blips, or this could be something much more significant.'' Norman Fosback, editor of a group of investment advisory letters published by the Institute for Econometric Research in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., plants himself squarely on the ``blip'' side of the argument. ``Price weakness touched off by the geopolitical crisis does NOT constitute a bear market,'' he declared in the firm's Mutual Fund Forecaster. ``It does appear to be the 10 percent to 15 percent correction that has been long overdue. ``Midstream bull market corrections are nearly always abrupt. They shake out the market's weak participants by leading them to believe, falsely, that a bear market has begun.'' One big risk behind this view is the chance that the market has looked beyond the Persian Gulf showdown and correctly discerned the approach of a recession. It will take a good while for these overlays of uncertainty to sort themselves out, observed Morton Silverman, portfolio strategist at Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood in Minneapolis. Silverman concluded, ``it's a time for prudence, not opportunism.''

DOC.HEAD: Sales Reheating for Wood Stoves
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Sales of wood stoves are heating up again as people worry about the rising cost of fuel for the winter. Wood stoves have been both maligned and romanticized as having a certain pioneer mystique. While oil price hikes and tensions in the Middle East fanned sales in the 1970s and early 1980s, wood stoves also were the target of pollution restrictions and the source of fatal house fires. Industry officials say stoves today have more sophisticated designs to remedy the old problems. Now wood stove makers and retailers are hoping to cash in on the Persian Gulf crisis, which they say demonstrates the risks of depending on oil. ``The good news for our industry is that there's been a wake-up call on the energy front,'' said Jim Hermann, president of the Earth Stove Inc., a Portland, Ore., company that is one of the largest wood stove producers in the country. ``We've been living in this artificial world of cheap oil.'' Stores that sell wood stoves say they saw surging interest in their products almost immediately after Iraq invaded Kuwait this month. In Massachusetts, the average price of home heating oil has risen 18 cents per gallon since the invasion. ``We had twice as many calls right off,'' said Peter Dormitzer, owner of the Chelmsford Fireplace Center north of Boston. One day last week, his store sold five stoves. ``We haven't been doing five stoves a month until now,'' he said. This growing interest comes as a sharp contrast to the industry's recent performance. More than a decade ago, the industry was growing so quickly that officials had no solid sales numbers. They estimated annual stove sales exceeded 1 million around the start of the 1980s, as large and small manufacturers proliferated around the country. ``Anybody that had a welding shop was putting together a wood stove back then,'' Hermann said. But for several reasons, the industry shrank quickly. Annual sales are now estimated around 225,000. A big factor was the falling price of oil, which meant people no longer were looking for another energy source. Instead, wood stoves increasingly were bought for aesthetic reasons, which meant they were ``competing with a new sofa or VCR,'' said Jason Densmore, of Lebanon, N.H., president of Wood Heating Alliance, a national trade association. Wood stoves also had a publicity problem. Mountain towns in Colorado, where air currents create special pollution problems, restricted numbers of wood stoves. In 1988, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency set new rules for wood stoves, forcing sharp reductions in smoke emissions. Meanwhile, fatal house fires were reported across the country in which wood stoves were involved. Industry officials say, however, these accidents usually were due to improper installation of the stoves or poor maintenance of chimneys. But these events have prompted the industry to change for the better, company representatives say. Because of the EPA restrictions, wood stoves today burn much more cleanly, and they are also made under tighter safety guidelines, said Jiggs Blackburn, research and development director for Vermont Castings Inc., a wood stove maker in Randolph, Vt. ``Wood stoves have undergone a remarkable transformation,'' Blackburn said. ``It is now a very sophisticated appliance.'' While the initial investment in a wood stove can exceed $1,000, wood stove representatives say the low price of wood compared with oil translates into savings over the long term. That is part of the sales pitch for people who might otherwise prefer the convenience of turning up their thermostats rather than gathering wood. Another advantage is simply the independence from foreign oil suppliers or local utilities, said Densmore, who noted he uses a wood stove to heat his 12-room house in central New Hampshire. ``I think we're certainly pleased to see the alternative fuel issue raised,'' he said. ``Unfortunately it takes something like this to create the awareness.''

DOC.HEAD: OPEC Ministers Urged to Convene Emergency Meeting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with six of seven necessary votes in favor of emergency conference on increasing oil production, edits to conform. No pickup; also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: OPEC appeared close Sunday to calling an emergency meeting to approve an increase in oil production because of the Persian Gulf crisis. A vote of seven nations is needed to call an emergency meeting, and the Venezuelan oil minister, Celestino Armas, said six countries already supported the measure. Armas, in Vienna for informal talks with other OPEC nations, said the oil market is suffering from ``an important disruption, and we have to do something about that.'' Since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, prompting a U.N. oil emargo on both nations, crude prices have risen from about $20 a barrel to more than $30, threatening the global economy. Ministers from 11 of the 13 member nations from the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries were in Vienna, site of the cartel's headquarters, for the talks. Those supporting an emergency meeting were Saudi Arabia, Venezuela, Kuwait, Qatar, Ecuador and the United Arab Emirates, Armas said. Saudi Arabia and Venezuela tried last week to call an emergency meeting on increasing production, but were rebuffed. Saudi Arabia, Venezuela, the United Arab Emirates and a few others have the ability to pump more crude oil. Some nations, like Iran, have argued that there is enough oil in storage to make up for any shortages caused by the gulf crisis. Only Iraq and Libya were not represented at Sunday's gathering, OPEC sources said on condition of anonymity. The finance minister of Kuwait's exiled government, Ali Khalifa al-Sabah, who was the conquered emirate's oil minister until earlier this summer, said Sunday he would like to see an increase in oil production. Saudi Arabia has said it intends to increase production by up to 2 million barrels a day _ with or without OPEC's blessing _ to make up some of the loss of crude caused by the Persian Gulf crisis. But clearly Saudi Arabia, the world's largest crude exporter, would like the cartel's approval to exceed its OPEC supply quota of 5.4 million barrels a day. Analysts estimate some 4 million barrels of crude a day have been pulled off the markets because of the international embargo on Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil. They said four other OPEC nations _ the United Arab Emirates, Venezuela, Nigeria and Libya _ also have the ability to pump extra oil. Venezuela's Armas said his country will boost output to fill its stocks because of the possibility that the oil crunch will continue for some time. Analysts say Venezuela could add as much as 500,000 barrels a day to its OPEC quota of 1.9 million barrels. OPEC President Sadek Boussena, the Algerian oil minister, echoed private analysts in saying that the cartel has had little impact on prices in recent weeks. The oil-consuming nations, he said, ``are masters of the prices.'' Last month, the cartel agreed to restrain production at 22.5 million barrels a day in the last half of the year in an effort to drive prices up to a new target of $21 a barrel. The benchmark was surpassed almost immediately because of the gulf crisis. OPEC nations are: Algeria, Ecuador, Gabon, Indonesia, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Libya, Nigeria, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Venezuela.

DOC.HEAD: Two Labor Unions Set Sights On Organizing Cable Industry
DOC.TEXT: Two labor unions hope to tap the booming cable industry for new membership in an effort to stem a decade-long decline in traditional membership. As revenue in the cable industry has mushroomed _ from about $2.9 billion in 1980 to $17.3 billion this year _ so has employment. An estimated 101,400 people currently work in the industry. The Communications Workers of America and the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers have begun focusing on organizing those workers, but it isn't easy. The CWA failed twice _ most recently in June _ to unionize United Cablevision, a subsidiary of United Artists Entertainment Inc. with roughly 130,000 subscribers in metropolitan Denver, though similar efforts at United's Grand Junction office succeeded. ``The difficulty you have is that each franchise has relatively few employees,'' said Morton Bahr, president of the CWA in Washington. ``This enables management to divide and conquer.'' Experts say unions represent workers in no more than 10 percent of the nearly 10,000 U.S. cable systems. By comparison, 100 percent of the regional Bell telephone companies are unionized. Ray McGuire, a Washington labor attorney, said the industry's relative youth has helped insulate it from unions. ``Cable has not been for a very long time a very profitable industry,'' he said. ``Cash flow was thin at the beginning.'' That changed during the 1980s, and now McGuire says the unions see cable's potential. The United Steelworkers of America found a receptive environment last fall at American Cablevision, which serves about 35,000 subscribers in the Denver area. Tim Richter and several co-workers drew on employees' dissatisfaction over wages, benefits and working conditions. Last November, employees voted for the union, and a second vote last month confirmed the previous election. But the cable companies view labor unions warily. ``If you have a strike or workplace disruption, you're going to have real upset customers,'' said Ron Christensen, vice president of human resources at Englewood-based Jones Intercable Inc. and chairman of the Cable Television Administration and Marketing's human resources committee. ``Although many unions are good unions, in a few cases you get an adversarial relationship,'' said Christensen. ``It's hard to say who's at fault, but it's a very unproductive environment.''
